ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Burial in streets, etc.; in lots, authorization, holding city harmless. 
No body shall be buried in any of the streets, lanes, nor walkways in any city cemetery. No body shall be buried in any lot in any city cemetery until after the written interment request has been properly executed by the lot owner or relative of the deceased or the funeral director in charge of the funeral arrangements. Such interment request shall be submitted to the sexton or cemetery superintendent at least 24 hours prior to the scheduled time of burial services. Such interment request shall be of the following form: 
INTERMENT REQUEST-CONSOLIDATED GOVERNMENT OF COLUMBUS, GEORGIA 
Date _______, 19 ___. 
You are hereby authorized and instructed, subject to your rules and regulations to enter the remains of _______Grave Space No._______, Lot No._______, Section_______ Cemetery_______ Owner of said lot being (or Deed) _______ 
The deceased was age _______, Sex _______, Social Security No. _______, Residence _______ DATE OF DEATH _______, DATE OF BIRTH _______ 
I hereby certify that I am the _______ 
(Relative, Lot Owner or Funeral Director) 
of the above named decedent and this is your authority to make disposition of the remains of said decedent as above indicated. I further certify and represent that I have the right and legal authority to direct this disposition of the decedent's remains in the aforestated lot and grave space, being aware of no ownership claims to the contrary, and I agree to hold the Consolidated Government of Columbus, Georgia harmless from any liability on account of said authorization and interment. 
Authorized Signature ___________ 
Address ___________ 
(Name of Funeral Director) 
This request shall be submitted to the sexton or cemetery superintendent not less than 24 hours before the burial service is scheduled. The burial service shall not be scheduled later than 4:30 p.m. 
I hereby authorize the above interment: 
Consolidated Government of Columbus, Georgia, By: ___________ 
The interment request shall be executed in triplicate, the original of which shall be filed at the cemetery, one copy shall be forwarded to the clerk of council for his files and the third copy shall be submitted to the funeral director in charge of the funeral arrangements. It shall be the duty of the sexton or the cemetery superintendent to obtain the executed interment request prior to the opening of the grave. 
(Code 1914, § 582; Ord. No. 72-197, § 1, 10-10-72; Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, 3-27-18, eff. 4-1-18) 
Sec. 9-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 72-197, § 2, adopted Oct. 10, 1972, repealed former § 9-2 pertaining to the issuance of a burial permit. Said section was derived from Code 1914, § 201. 
Sec. 9-3. - Disposition of the remains of indigent persons. 
In order to satisfy the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-12-5 and O.C.G.A. § 31-21-21, pertaining to deceased indigents, Columbus will undertake the following obligations. The determination of indigency will be made by the Columbus Office of the Department of Human Resources, Division of Family and Children Services (DFACS). Once that determination is certified by DFACS and provided to the cemetery sexton, Columbus will offer the following options to dispose of the remains: 
(1)  Where the person asserting the right to direct the disposition of the body under O.C.G.A. § 31-21-7 ("the authorizing agent") authorizes cremation of the indigent, he or she must authorize the funeral home to release the cremains into the custody of the cemetery sexton in lieu of any other direction which might otherwise be made pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-18-80. The cemetery sexton will accept all indigent cremains for any indigent so certified by DFACS for storage in a vault. Upon notification from the sexton of acceptance of the cremains and certification from the funeral home that all necessary steps to apply for a death certificate have been completed, the director of public works shall pay the funeral home which provided the cremation service a fee of $600.00. 
(2)  Where burial is requested by the authorizing agent, the cemetery sexton will provide a grave space and grave opening in the pauper burial ground. All indigents shall be buried at a time and date approved by the sexton. The funeral home which has custody of the body, and provides for its transportation and burial will receive a payment in the amount of $400.00 upon certification to the director of public works from the sexton that the burial is complete and certification of the funeral home that all necessary steps to apply for a death certificate have been completed. 
(3)  Once the remains of an individual have been tendered to the city for burial or storage pursuant to subsections (1) or (2) above, any requests for the release of cremains, the marking of a burial plot, or the disinterment of a body for burial elsewhere will be made to the cemetery sexton who shall require reimbursement of any funds expended by the city in connection with the initial burial or cremation as well as any additional costs to be incurred by the city in accommodating the requested alternative disposition; provided however, the director of the department of public works will have the authority to waive some or all the required fees upon an administrative investigation and a finding that a full or partial waiver is warranted by the financial circumstances of the authorizing agent requesting such treatment and other compelling circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 13-7, § 1, 2-5-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-7, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 2013, repealed the former § 9-3, and enacted a § 9-3 as set out herein. The § 9-3 pertained to paupers; ground; expense; certificate and derived from the Code of 1914, § 587; and Ord. No. 72-197, § 3, adopted 10-10-72. 
State Law reference— As to city as trustee of cemeteries, see Ga. Code, § 69-503, which section is included in Part II of this volume. 
Sec. 9-4. - Sale of lots; receipt; deed. 
The selling of previously unowned lots in the cemeteries owned by the city shall be done by the city clerk, who shall make out and deliver to the purchaser upon receipt of the purchase money, a deed to the same, which deed shall be signed by the mayor and the clerk, upon behalf of the city. 
All deeds shall contain the stipulation that they are issued pursuant to this chapter, and are subject to the terms hereof. 
Effective April 1, 2018, it shall be required that all secondary transfers of lots originally purchased pursuant to this section shall be filed with the clerk of the city at the time of transfer in order for such deed to authorize burial in a designated lot. The clerk shall also accept any prior secondary transfers for recording in accordance with this code section. 
Effective April 1, 2018, all burials in a city lot will require one of the following: 1) proof of family relationship to the last lot owner shown by the records of the sextant; 2) the existence of a deed of purchase filed with the clerk of council in accordance with the above referenced paragraph; 3) a certified copy of a deed filed with the Clerk of the Superior Court of Muscogee County. 
(Code 1914, § 583; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 28; Ord. No. 74-32, § 1, 2-5-74; Ord. No. 18-9, § 2, 3-27-18, eff. 4-1-18) 
Sec. 9-5. - Vehicles in cemeteries—Those prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any automobile, truck, dray, wagon, taxicab or other business vehicle to enter or pass through the city cemeteries in the city except when such vehicles are actually engaged in delivering or receiving materials, articles or passengers in such cemeteries. 
(Code 1914, § 584; Ord. of 8-29-36, § 1) 
Sec. 9-6. - Same—Funeral processions, other; speed; turning; in driveways only. 
Funeral processions, upon entering a city cemetery, shall be under the control and subject to the direction of the sexton. Automobiles or other vehicles shall not be allowed to proceed at a greater speed than ten miles per hour when within the cemetery enclosure. Such vehicles shall not turn around in the driveways but must continue to the next street intersection before turning. All vehicles shall remain at all times within the confines of the established driveways. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, §§ 11, 34; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 24) 
Sec. 9-7. - Injury to property, trees, etc.—Picnicking; firearms. 
No person in the city cemeteries shall pick flowers of any kind, break branches from shrubs or trees, or climb fences to the cemeteries or trees located therein. Picnicking, lunching, lounging, shooting or loud and boisterous or disorderly conduct are forbidden in the cemeteries. No person with firearms shall be permitted to enter the cemetery grounds. 
(Code 1914, § 585; Ord. of 10-14-24, § 33; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 23) 
Cross reference— Planting trees and shrubs, § 9-16; planting trees in perpetual care sections, § 9-27. 
Sec. 9-8. - Same—Reward. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to offer a reward of $100.00 for information leading to the conviction of any persons guilty of committing depredations in the cemetery. 
(Code 1914, § 588; Ord. No. 72-197, § 4, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-9. - Rubbish—Removal, time allowed. 
All piles of earth, brick, mortar beds, rubbish or building materials of any kind shall be removed by the party placing the same in the city cemeteries within 24 hours after the completion of any work which may be done in the cemetery. 
All broken copings, monuments and stones shall be removed by owners of cemetery lots within 30 days. 
All sunken lots and graves shall be filled and leveled by owners of cemetery lots within 30 days. 
(Code 1914, § 586; Ord. No. 66-30, § 1, 3-7-66) 
Cross reference— Disposition of garbage, trash and waste, § 13-167 et seq. 
Sec. 9-10. - Same—Placing or leaving. 
The placing or leaving of empty cans, flower pots, vases, weeds, decayed flowers or plants or any rubbish, on the lots or in the streets of the city cemeteries is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 32; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 22) 
Sec. 9-11. - Children, unattended; sexton's duty. 
It shall be unlawful for children under the age of 12 years to enter into or upon the grounds of any cemetery of the city unless such child be accompanied by some older person, and it is hereby made the duty of the sextons of the cemeteries to see that this section is enforced. 
(Code 1914, § 589) 
Sec. 9-12. - Dogs prohibited; sexton's duty. 
No dog shall be allowed to enter a cemetery enclosure. It shall be the duty of the sexton, to inform persons visiting the grounds, of this section and also to report all violations hereof. 
(Code 1914, § 590) 
Cross reference— Control of dogs and cats, § 5-10. 
Sec. 9-13. - Grave opening and closing fees. 
The cemetery superintendent shall receive each of the following applicable fees as listed: 

 
(Code 1914, § 592; Ord. No. 58-15, § 2; Ord. No. 58-28, § 1; Ord. No. 63-37, § 1, 4-22-63; Ord. No. 69-88, § 1, 5-26-69; Ord. No. 69-193, § 1, 10-20-69; Ord. No. 72-197, § 5, 10-10-72; Ord. No. 74-32, § 2, 2-5-74; Ord. No. 81-39, § 1, 5-12-81; Ord. No. 97-68, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 97-110, 9-30-97; Ord. No. 03-45, § 3, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 16-25, § 1, 6-14-16; Ord. No. 18-9, § 3, 3-27-18; Ord. No. 18-9, § 3, 3-27-18, eff. 4-1-18) 
Sec. 9-14. - New enclosures; approval. 
No new fences, walls, copings or other enclosures shall be placed upon or around any private burial lot in the cemeteries of the city, except upon plans submitted to and approved by the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1914, § 594) 
Cross reference— Further provisions relevant to enclosures, § 9-26. 
Sec. 9-15. - Repair of structures; changing location. 
In repairing any fences, walls or copings now in use the work shall be done as directed by the superintendent of public works and when such repairs are made the superintendent of public works shall have authority to change the location of the walls, copings or fencing in order to make them correspond with the lines of the streets and alleys as nearly as possible, the work to be done under the direction of such superintendent. 
(Code 1914, § 595) 
Sec. 9-16. - Trees, shrubs; planting, permit. 
The planting of all shrubs and all trees, other than flowers, in the cemeteries of the city shall be done only after permission first has been obtained from the superintendent of public works and shall be done under the supervision and direction of the sexton of the cemetery where planted. 
(Code 1914, § 800) 
Cross reference— For further provisions relevant to trees, see §§ 9-7, 9-27. 
Sec. 9-17. - Hours of admission. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any cemetery in the city between the hours beginning at sunset and ending at seven o'clock a.m. except by permission of the sexton of such cemetery, unless otherwise specifically provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 3-28-33, § 1; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 14) 
Sec. 9-17.1. - Supervision, superintendent of public works. 
The supervision of all the streets and alleys in the cemetery belonging to the city is hereby placed under the direction and control of the superintendent of public works with full power and authority to keep and maintain the same in suitable condition for travel thereon and to do this, said superintendent shall have authority to make surveys, establish lines and grades. 
The superintendent of public works shall also have full power and authority and he is hereby obligated to go upon any lot which is not kept up to the standards required of owners by sections 9-9 and 9-10 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Columbus and to do any and all things the owners themselves are thereby obligated to do but which have not been done by the owners within the time required, or which the owners have suffered to exist in violation of the requirements of said sections. Nothing herein shall be construed as relieving the owners of any lot of keeping the said lot up to said standards, nor shall it be construed as interfering with the obligations of the City of Columbus regarding upkeep under the perpetual care program. 
(Code 1914, § 593; Ord. No. 66-30, § 2, 3-7-66) 
ARTICLE II. - PERPETUAL CARE SECTIONS 

Sec. 9-18. - Definition of term. 
The term "perpetual care", as used herein, means the sodding of graves, the cutting of grass upon lots and graves at reasonable intervals, the raking and cleaning of lots and of grave surfaces, the care and pruning of lots and trees, and the keeping in repair of enclosures, streets, walks and borders, so that such entire perpetual care sections shall present a neat and uniform appearance. 
The term "perpetual care", as used herein, does not mean the maintaining, repairing or replacing of any grave stone or monumental structure erected upon a lot in such sections. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 39; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 25) 
Sec. 9-19. - Description of sections. 
(a)  Eastern part of Linwood Cemetery. The eastern part of Linwood Cemetery in the city is hereby established as a perpetual care section, such section comprising lots numbers one to 298, both inclusive, together with the streets contiguous to such lots, all as shown on that certain drawing in the office of the city engineer, dated October 20, 1947, and entitled "Drawing No. D-127, Perpetual Care Section of Linwood Cemetery". A copy of such drawing is of record in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Muscogee County, Georgia, in Plat Book five, page 176. 
(b)  Riverdale Cemetery. Central Circle, Sections 11, 12, 13, 15-B, 42-A, 42-B and 42-C. 
(b.1) East Porterdale Cemetery. All grave spaces sold since August 4, 1969. 
(c)  Other individually owned lots. All other individually owned lots not described in subsections (a), (b) and (b.1) above are hereby declared to be perpetual care sections, upon compliance by the owner with the provisions of section 9-21 relating to perpetual care charges of all other individually owned lots. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 1; Ord. No. 61-27, § 1, 3-27-61; Ord. No. 72-197, § 5, 10-10-72; Ord. No. 74-32, § 3, 2-5-74) 
Sec. 9-20. - Authority in charge. 
The superintendent of public works of the city, hereinafter designated "superintendent", shall have charge of all perpetual care sections in the city, and is authorized to enforce the provisions hereof. Subject to the orders of the city manager, the superintendent is authorized to maintain order, to supervise all workmen, visitors and drivers, to expel from the grounds any improper person, or those who violate the rules, and to refuse admission to any person or materials when he may deem such action necessary. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 1; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 1) 
Sec. 9-21. - Purchase price; perpetual care charge. 
(a)  Linwood Cemetery. The purchase price of each lot in the perpetual care section of Linwood Cemetery shall be on the basis of $0.50 per square foot, receipts from such sales to become part of the general operations fund of the city. 
In addition to such purchase price, the purchaser shall pay to the city, at the time of purchase, $1.25 per square foot for perpetual care of such lot, such charge for perpetual care to be deposited in the perpetual care fund hereinafter provided for. 
(b)  Riverdale Cemetery. Such fees and charges for Riverdale Cemetery are as set by resolution of the city commission. 
(c)  Other individually owned lots. The owners of individually owned lots not described in subsections (a) and (b) of section 9-19 are hereby authorized to place their individually owned lots under perpetual care by the payment to the city of the sum of $600.00 for each lot. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 26; Ord. No. 61-27, § 2, 3-27-61) 
Sec. 9-22. - Fund, Linwood Cemetery; deposit; investing. 
There is hereby established a perpetual care fund for the perpetual care section of Linwood Cemetery, to be composed of funds received from the charges for perpetual care, as set forth in the preceding section hereof. The moneys of such fund shall be deposited by the treasury of the city in a bank or banks in the city, kept separate from all other funds in the custody of the city, and shall be designated on the books of the treasurer and on the accounts of the bank or banks in which such funds are deposited as "Linwood Cemetery Perpetual Care Fund." 
From time to time, as charges for perpetual care are accumulated by the city and paid into such perpetual care fund, such funds shall be invested by the treasurer and the city manager in interest-bearing securities which are now, or which may be at the time of such investment, legal investments for trustees under the laws of Georgia. The power to invest such funds shall include the power, from time to time, to reinvest such funds in the class of securities in this section named. 
The perpetual care fund hereby established shall be used solely for the perpetual care of such section of Linwood Cemetery, as the term "Perpetual Care" is defined in section 9-18 hereof. 
It is the intention hereof that the income and not the corpus, of such perpetual care fund shall be used for the perpetual care of such section of Linwood Cemetery; provided, however, pending the time when such perpetual care fund has accumulated to an amount as will produce an income sufficient for the care of such section as contemplated by this article, such portions of the corpus as may be necessary may be used for the care of such section. 
(Ord. of 5-17-49, § 27) 
Sec. 9-22.1. - Fund, individually owned lots. 
There is hereby established a perpetual care fund for the perpetual care of individually owned lots as described in subsection (c) of section 9-19 of this code. The moneys of such fund shall be deposited by the treasurer of the city, kept separate from all other funds in the custody of the city, and shall be designated on the books of the treasurer and on the accounts of the bank or banks in which such funds are deposited as "Cemetery Perpetual Care Fund under Sec. 9-19 (c)." Such perpetual care fund shall be operated in the same manner and for the same purposes and intention as expressed in section 9-22 for the Linwood Cemetery Fund. 
(Ord. No. 61-27, § 3, 3-27-61) 
Note— Section 3 of Ord. No. 61-27 amended the Code by adding § 9-22.1 as set out above. 
Sec. 9-23. - Sale—Subject to rules. 
All lots to be sold in such perpetual care section shall be subject to the rules and regulations relating to cemeteries in the city now of force or which may hereafter be adopted and which do not conflict with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 3; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 2; Ord. No. 70-22, § 1, 1-26-70) 
Note— Ord. No. 70-22, § 1, amended § 9-23 by deleting the last sentence which limited the use of lots to the burial of persons of the Caucasian race. 
Cross reference— For further provisions relevant to sale of lots, see § 9-4. 
Sec. 9-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 72-197, § 7, adopted Oct. 10, 1972, repealed former § 9-24 pertaining to the sale of lots in Riverdale Cemetery. Said section was derived from Ord. of Oct. 14, 1924, § 5. 
Sec. 9-25. - Perpetual care to apply; extra improvements, instructions. 
All lots and graves in such perpetual care sections shall be sold subject to perpetual care, as hereinafter defined, and maintained under the direction of the superintendent. Extra improvements and embellishments of lots and graves shall be done in accordance with this chapter and with instructions issued by the superintendent in each instance. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 4; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 3) 
Sec. 9-26. - Enclosures prohibited; corner stones, position. 
No enclosure of any nature, such as fences, copings, hedges, ditches, flower beds or other means of marking boundaries of lots or graves shall be used in such perpetual care sections, except corner stones to lots. Such corner stones shall be set even with the surface of the ground and only by cemetery employees. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 7; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 4) 
Cross reference— For other provisions relevant to enclosures, see § 9-14. 
Sec. 9-27. - Trees, shrubs, etc.; planting, pruning; removal. 
No trees, shrubs, plants or flowers may be planted other than in conformity with the general landscape plan of such perpetual care section, and the same shall not be planted, pruned or removed without the consent of the superintendent. 
Acting for the best interest of the cemetery, the superintendent shall have the authority to prune, remove or transplant any tree, shrub, plant, flower or anything upon a lot, when he may consider such course necessary. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 8; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 5) 
Cross reference— For other provisions relevant to trees, see §§ 9-7, 9-16. 
Sec. 9-28. - Ornamental trinkets; removal without notice. 
Glass boxes, artificial flowers, shells, toys, settees or ornaments of any kind shall not be allowed upon lots or graves, and will be removed by cemetery employees without notice; chairs, settees, vases or urns which are broken or in dilapidated condition will be removed by cemetery employees without notice. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 9; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 6) 
Sec. 9-29. - Mounds; established grades. 
Grave mounds shall not be allowed. No part of any lot or grave shall be raised above the established grade. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 10; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 7) 
Sec. 9-30. - Markers; specifications; location. 
Only one single marker will be permitted to each grave and this marker shall be placed at the head of the grave. All single markers must be at least four inches in height, not less than eight nor more than 14 inches in width, and not more than 24 inches in length; the top of the marker to be set level with and following the contour of the ground. No single marker shall be set to embrace more than one grave. Markers on any lot must be uniform in size and material and shall be made of marble or granite. Double markers shall not be permitted to embrace more than two graves abutting side by side and such marker shall be placed at the head of the abutting graves. Double markers shall be at least four inches in thickness, not less than eight nor more than 14 inches in width, and not more than six feet in length. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 20; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 8; Ord. No. 72-197, § 8, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-31. - Monument—Foundation; specifications; construction supervision. 
The foundations for all monuments, mausoleums, tombs or vaults must be of solid masonry or concrete and of sufficient size and depth for the superstructure, the upper surface to be at least two inches below the established lot surface, and shall be built under the direction of the superintendent at the expense of the lot owner. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 24; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 10) 
Sec. 9-32. - Same—Removal; permission. 
Where markers or monuments are placed upon any lot sold, no removal of same shall be permitted to be made under claim that they are not paid for, nor for other reasons, without authority from the owner of the lot and the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 26; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 12) 
Sec. 9-33. - Same—Number allowed; location. 
(a)  Linwood Cemetery. To avoid the crowding of monuments, and consequent unsightly appearance of the grounds, only one monument will be allowed on each numbered lot of the perpetual care section of Linwood Cemetery; and such monument shall be located in accordance with one of the typical lot plans kept on record in the office of the superintendent. 
(b)  Riverdale Cemetery. To avoid the crowding of monuments and consequent unsightly appearance of the grounds, no monument in Riverdale Cemetery will be allowed on a tract covering less than 200 square feet, and only one monument, mausoleum, tomb or vault will be allowed on any tract, and such monument, mausoleum, tomb or vault shall be located in accordance with one of the various typical lot plans on record in the office of the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 11-18-35, § 21; Ord. of 10-14-24, § 9; Ord. No. 72-197, § 9, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-34. - Same——Like design in Riverdale Cemetery. 
Not more than one monument, mausoleum, tomb or vault of the same design shall be erected in the same section of Riverdale Cemetery without special permission of the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 22) 
Sec. 9-35. - Same—Charges paid before placing. 
No monument shall be allowed to be placed on a lot against which any charges remain unpaid. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 18) 
Sec. 9-36. - Same—Size in Riverdale Cemetery; submitting plan. 
No monument, mausoleum, tomb or vault shall cover more than ten percent of the ground space of the lot. The design and specifications of monuments, mausoleums, tombs and vaults must first be submitted to the superintendent for approval. The placing or setting of work shall not be allowed without the consent of the superintendent. 
No monument shall be less than eight inches thick, not less than 24 inches nor more than 36 inches in height, above the ground surface. No monument base shall exceed 24 inches in width nor five feet in length nor six inches in thickness. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 23; Ord. No. 72-197, § 9, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-37. - Same—Deposit before erection in Riverdale Cemetery. 
Before any vault, tomb, or mausoleum is erected above ground, the proprietor must deposit with the city treasurer a sum equal to 15 percent of the cost of such structure, such sum to be added to the perpetual care fund and the income used for the proper care of such structure. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 28) 
Sec. 9-38. - Construction work; time for completion. 
All construction work must be completed as fast as possible under the direction of the superintendent, and materials not used must be removed as the work is completed. No material shall be received and no work shall be started on Saturday which cannot be completed on that day. In order to protect the lawns from injury, heavy material must be moved over planks placed for that purpose. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 25; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 11) 
Sec. 9-39. - Extra work; payment; supervision. 
If extra work is required, such as a concrete vault, decorating grave, furnishing lowering device, shelter tent, etc., the charges must be paid when the order is given. All such work is to be done by cemetery employees only, under the direction of the superintendent, at the expense of the lot owner. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 13; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 13) 
Sec. 9-40. - Workmen; control of superintendent. 
Within the confines of the cemetery, all workmen shall be subject to the direction and control of the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 30; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 15) 
Sec. 9-41. - One interment in same grave; exception. 
In the perpetual acre sections only one interment shall be made in the same grave, except the mother and infant, or two children in one casket. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 14; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 16) 
Sec. 9-42. - Burial; certificate required; digging ordered, time. 
No interment shall be permitted or body received unless the proper burial certificate is furnished by the commissioner of health of Muscogee County, Georgia; the certificate to give the name and residence of the deceased, the name of the nearest relative, and the time, place and cause of death. Digging of graves must be ordered at least eight working hours before the interment is to take place. 
Funeral directors whose principle place of business is located in Columbus, Georgia or Phenix City, Alabama who hold a valid business license issued by the consolidated government of Columbus, Georgia and who are in good standing with said consolidated government shall be allowed 30 days from date of interment to file said burial permit with the clerk of council. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 2; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 17; Ord. No. 72-197, § 11, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-43. - Disinterment—By whom made; consent. 
No disinterment shall be made except by cemetery employees with the written consent of the commissioner of health of Muscogee County, Georgia, and of the next-of-kin of the deceased. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 15; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 18) 
Sec. 9-44. - Same—Charges, paid in advance. 
All fees and charges representing purchase price of cemetery lots and grave spaces and all charges for interments, disinterments, grave openings and other work or services shall be paid in advance, provided however, all funeral directors whose principle place of business is located in Columbus, Georgia or Phenix City, Alabama and who are in good standing with consolidated government of Columbus, Georgia and holding a valid business license issued by said consolidated government, shall have the privilege of allowing such fees and charges to accrue to the last day of the month during which such charges and fees were incurred. All such charges and fees shall be due and payable to the consolidated government on or before the tenth day of the month following the month in which such charges and fees were incurred. In the event a funeral director fails to pay his account in full by said due date such funeral director shall no longer have the privilege of accruing his account until all past due charges and fees have been paid in full. All funeral directors whose principle place of business is not located within Columbus, Georgia or Phenix City, Alabama shall not be permitted to make any interments or disinterments in city owned cemeteries until all charges and fees in connection therewith have been paid in full in advance and the proper burial permit or state transmittal permit has been submitted to the sexton or cemetery superintendent. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 17; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 19; Ord. No. 72-197, § 12, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 72-197, § 13, adopted Oct. 10, 1972, repealed former § 9-45, derived from Ord. of Oct. 14, 1924, § 16. Said section pertained to charges for removal of a body from a single grave in Riverdale Cemetery. 
Sec. 9-46. - Advertisements; signs. 
Dealers' and manufacturers' cards or advertisements shall not be cut or marked on any stone or placed anywhere within the cemetery enclosure. No sign indicating that a lot, portion of lot, tomb or stone, nor any other material or articles located in such cemeteries is for sale, shall be permitted in such section. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24 §,§ 29, 38; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 20) 
Sec. 9-47. - Leaving articles; responsibility of city. 
The city will not be responsible for loss or damage to markers, monuments, copings, fences or any other article placed or left upon any lot, grave or any other part of the cemetery. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 31; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 21; Ord. No. 72-197, § 14, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-48. - Speculation in lots; forfeiture. 
To avoid speculation in lots, no lot, after being sold by the city, shall be resold at any time by a purchaser for a consideration in excess of the amount which the city currently receives for a similar size lot, plus the separate charges, if any, collected by the city prior to the date of resale for perpetual care purposes. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 6; Ord. of 5-17-49, § 26; Ord. No. 72-197, § 15, 10-10-72) 
Sec. 9-49. - Assignment of lots, Riverdale Cemetery; consent of superintendent. 
No sale or assignment of any lot or part of any lot in Riverdale Cemetery shall be valid without the consent of the superintendent endorsed on the conveyance. Lot owners shall not allow interments on their lots for a remuneration. 
(Ord. of 10-14-24, § 6) 
Secs. 9-50—9-52. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 9-50, prohibiting cemetery employees from accepting fees or tips and providing that accounts be settled at the office; § 9-51, excluding persons violating cemetery rules from the grounds; and § 9-52, providing for changing cemetery rules, were repealed by Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, adopted May 23, 1978. Said sections were derived from Ord. of Oct. 14, 1924, §§ 36, 37, 39. 
Sec. 9-53. - Burial of animals, etc., prohibited. 
All city cemeteries are reserved for the purpose of burying the remains of members of the human race. The burying of the remains or carcasses of animals, fowls or pets of any kind in any city owned or controlled cemetery is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 72-197, § 16, 10-10-72) 
Chapter 10 - DEALERS IN SECONDHAND JEWELRY, PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Fleamarkets, Ch. 11B; junk and scrap metal dealers, § 14-41; purchase and sale of articles commonly stolen and traded, § 14-81 et seq.; pawnbrokers, Ch. 15. 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
Dealer in gold and silver shall mean any person engaged in whole or in part, in the business of buying, trading or selling coins, jewelry, gold, silver, precious metals, etc., of any description from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers. 
Gems. The following stones are hereby designated "gems" for the purpose of this chapter: Diamonds, emeralds, rubies and sapphires. 
Person shall mean an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association or any other legal entity, however organized. 
Precious metals shall mean the following: 
(1)  Gold: 
(a)  Metallic items, 100 percent gold—24-karat; 
(b)  Metallic items, 75 percent gold—18-karat; 
(c)  Metallic items, 56.25 percent gold—14-karat; 
(d)  Metallic items, 39.1 percent gold—10-karat; 
(e)  Metallic items, 29 percent to 39 percent gold—7-to 9-karat; 
(f)  Metallic items, 20 percent gold or greater by weight. 
(Metallic items of less quantity than 20 percent gold by weight or content shall be nonprecious metal.) 
(2)  Silver: 
(a)  All 100 percent silver metal items—Pure silver; 
(b)  All 92.5 percent silver metal items—Sterling silver; 
(c)  All 90 percent silver metal items—Coin silver; 
(d)  All 80 percent silver metal items—European silver; 
(e)  All metallic items of silver containing 50 percent or more silver by weight or content. 
(Metallic items of less quantity than 50 percent silver by weight or content are not termed precious metals.) 
(3)  Platinum: All metallic items containing platinum are declared to be precious metals. 
(4)  Iridium: All metallic items containing iridium are declared to be precious metals. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-2. - Business license—Required; application. 
Any person within Columbus, Georgia, shall, before engaging in whole or in part, in the business of buying, trading or selling coins, jewelry, gold, silver, precious metals, etc., from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers, file with the revenue collection division of Columbus, Georgia, an application for a business license to conduct and carry on said business as a dealer in gold and silver. The revenue collection division shall furnish the Columbus Police Department with a copy of said application at which time the police department shall verify the criminal criteria in the application and furnish the revenue collection division with their findings and recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-3. - Same—Exemptions. 
The provisions hereof shall not apply when the item traded in is an item originally purchased from the dealer to whom it is traded. Said dealer shall be required, however, to demand positive identification of person trading in such item to demand proof that said person is the legal owner of such item. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-4. - Same—Restrictions. 
No such license shall be issued to: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community; 
(3)  A person who has been convicted of a felony or crime involving theft-related offenses within five years of issuance or renewal of license; 
(4)  A person whose license under this chapter has been revoked for cause; 
(5)  A person who, at the time of the application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license under first application; 
(6)  A copartnership, unless one of the members of such copartnership owning not less than five percent interest therein shall be qualified to obtain such a license; 
(7)  A corporation if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate of more than five percent of the stock in such corporation would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than a residence within Columbus, Georgia; 
(8)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81; Ord. No. 83-4, § 1, 2-22-83; Ord. No. 95-26, 4-18-95) 
Sec. 10-5. - Same—Application requirements; oath. 
(A)  The application for said business shall be signed and dated by the applicant and contain answers to the following questions: 
(1)  What is the kind of business to be operated? 
(2)  What is the name of the business? 
(3)  What is the location where such business is proposed to be carried on and the telephone number of said location? 
(4)  What is the name of the applicant for the license, and the home address and telephone number of said applicant? 
(5)  Where has applicant resided for the six months preceding the date of this application? 
(6)  What was the applicant's previous home address, and how long was applicant a resident there? 
(7)  What is the Social Security number of said applicant? 
(8)  Applicant intends to do business as: 
Individual; or 
Partnership; or 
Corporation? 
(9)  Personnel of applicant: If the applicant is an individual, name the individual applying; if a partnership, name all the members of the partnership; if a corporation, name the president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer, as well as the board of directors; list all employees by name, title (individual, partner or corporation), age and residence address. 
(10)  Who is the landlord or owner of said location, and what is the address and telephone number of said landlord or owner? 
(11)  Has the applicant or any person connected with, employed by or having any interest in said business: 
(a)  Been charged or convicted of any violation of law (other than minor traffic violations) in any locality? 
(b)  Served time in prison, or other correctional institution? 
(12)  If the answer to section (a) of the above question is "yes," state the circumstances in detail. Information must be complete as to dates, charges, court jurisdiction and disposition for each person. If the answer to section (b) of the above question is "yes," state the circumstances in detail. Information must be complete as to the charge on which convicted, name of prison or correctional institution, length of time served, date of release from prison or correctional institution, whether sentence has been completed, or whether on probation or parole, and the terms thereof. 
(13)  Give the name, home address and telephone number and place of employment of two persons who are residents of Columbus, Georgia, who are familiar with your character and reputation. 
(B)  The following oath shall be required on the application: 
"All of the following information is hereby given and all of the foregoing statements are hereby made on oath, willfully, knowingly and absolutely, and the same is hereby sworn to be true under penalty for false swearing, as provided by law. 

Sworn to and subscribed before me, this_______day of_______, 19_______. 

(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-6. - Same—Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Council of Columbus, Georgia, shall have the right and privilege of granting or declining, within 60 days of the date of application, a business license to conduct said business, and if the same shall be granted, it shall be subject, however, to suspension or revocation for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing and upon three days' prior written notice to holder of such receipt, the time, place and purpose of such hearing, and a statement of the charges upon which such hearing shall be held. Due cause for the suspension or revocation of such business license shall consist of a violation of any provision of this chapter or violation of any state or federal law involving theft-related offenses by the person or any officer, agent, representative or employee of the person. 
(b)  Said business license shall not be transferable from person to person or location to location and shall expire at the end of each calendar year and may be renewable only in the manner and form provided in this section. 
(c)  Those persons who held valid 1980 licenses pertaining to secondhand jewelry, gold and precious metals and who are in good standing shall, upon filing an application under this chapter, be allowed to continue an operation until such time as a 1981 license has been issued or denied without suffering any penalty for late purchase of such license under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-7. - Same—Rate. 
The business license rate for the above-described business shall be $300.00 for each location. Any licensed pawnbroker or jeweler wishing to transact business under this chapter shall be required to fulfill all requirements under this chapter and shall pay a fee of $100.00 per year in addition to any other license fee issued under any other ordinance or ordinances. Provided, however, that all such licenses shall be issued to the same location. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-8. - Gross receipts tax. 
The gross receipts tax under this chapter shall be $2.50 per $1,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-9. - Rules and regulations. 
The following rules and regulations are hereby established, and shall govern the conduct and operation of every such place of business, and every person owning and operating such place of business: 
(1)  Contents of record book. Every person shall maintain a book, in permanent form in which shall be entered in legible English at the time of each purchase or sale the following information: 
(a)  The date of the transaction; 
(b)  The name of the person conducting the transaction; 
(c)  The name and address of the customer, a description of the general appearance of the customer; and the number from the customer's valid driver's license, military I.D. card, alcoholic beverage card, or any other means of identification that contains birthdate, sex, race and address; 
(d)  An identification and description of the purchased goods, or sold goods, including, if reasonably available, the serial, model or other number, and all identifying marks inscribed thereon. In addition, the dealer shall furnish any other identifying information that may be required on forms prescribed and furnished to dealer by the Columbus Police Department; 
(e)  The price paid; 
(f)  The number of the check issued for the purchase price; and 
(g)  The signature of the customer. 
(2)  Recorded entries; availability for inspection. Entries shall appear in chronological order in ink. No blank lines may be left between entries. No obliterations, alterations or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. The book shall be open to the inspection of any officer of the Columbus Police Department or representative of the revenue collection division's office during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time. 
(3)  Maintenance period for records. The record of each purchase or sale transaction, as herein provided, shall be maintained for a period of not less than two years. 
(4)  Holding period for merchandise. All merchandise purchased shall be maintained for inspection by an officer of the Columbus Police Department or representative of the revenue collection division's office for a period of not less than 15 days after the date of purchase. All items shall be maintained in the same condition as they existed when purchased by dealer; provided, however, that a licensee under this chapter need not hold such items for 15 days if he has purchased them from another licensee under this chapter who has held the same items for the required 15 days. 
(5)  Purchases from minors. No merchandise shall be purchased from any individual under 18 years of age. 
(6)  List of employees required. Each person shall be required to furnish an updated list to the Columbus Police Department of all new employees, whether temporary or permanent. All employees shall be subject to a thorough police check along the same standards as set forth for the licensee, except for residency. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 10-10. - Violation; penalty. 
All persons failing to comply with this chapter shall be punished according to section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of Columbus, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 81-20, § 1, 3-5-81)

ARTICLE II. - WETLANDS PROTECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 00-18, adopted Feb. 15, 2000, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as Art. II, §§ 10B-31—10B-34, of this chapter was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 10B-31. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to assist in the identification and protection of freshwater wetlands in Columbus/Muscogee County. 
(Ord. No. 00-18, § A, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-32. - Definition of freshwater wetlands. 
"Wetlands" means those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soils. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs and similar areas. The ecological parameters for designating wetlands include hydric soils, hydrophytic vegetation, and hydrological conditions that involve a temporary or permanent source of water to cause soil saturation. Freshwater wetlands do not include any areas defined as "coastal marshlands" by the State Coastal Marshlands Protection Act. 
(Ord. No. 00-18, § B, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-33. - Minimum protection criteria for wetlands. 
(a)  The natural resources study map depicting wetlands shall be updated in the Columbus Comprehensive Plan to reflect all wetlands over five acres according to the National Wetlands Inventory Map. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of any building permits by the inspections and codes enforcement division, areas depicted as wetlands according to the aforementioned map will require coordination with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for a jurisdictional wetlands determination and possibly a section 404 permit. The Consolidated Government of Columbus Engineering Department shall compare the sites of the proposed projects to the wetlands map and if necessary refer developers to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, before issuing a report back to the inspections and codes enforcement division on approval of such projects. 
(Ord. No. 00-18, § C, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-34. - Wetlands protected areas overlay district map. 
The official map shall be known as the "wetlands protected areas overlay district map" and is attached as part of this article (Map C) for information. 
(Ord. No. 00-18, § C, 2-15-00) 
Editor's note— The wetlands protected areas overlay district map referenced in § 10B-34 above has not been included within this Code, but may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Secs. 10B-35—10B-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GROUNDWATER RECHARGE PROTECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 00-19, adopted Feb. 15, 2000, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as Art. III, §§ 10B-51—10B-54, of this chapter was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 10B-51. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to insure the protection of the groundwater supply in Columbus and Muscogee County. This can be achieved by: 
(1)  Protecting groundwater quality by restricting land uses that generate, use, or store dangerous pollutants in recharge areas. 
(2)  Protecting groundwater quality by limiting density of future development in recharge areas; and 
(3)  Protecting groundwater quality by ensuring that any development that occurs within the recharge areas shall have no adverse affect on groundwater quality. 
(Ord. No. 00-19, § A, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-52. - Definitions. 
The following definitions are terminology used by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources in developing the location maps of significant groundwater recharge areas and pollution susceptibility. 
Aquifer means any stratum or zone of rock beneath the surface of the earth capable of containing or producing water from a well. 
DRASTIC means the standardized system for evaluating groundwater pollution potential using the hydro geologic settings described in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency document EPA-600/ 2-87-035. The term "DRASTIC" is an acronym derived from the seven hydro geologic parameters deemed most influential to pollution susceptibility. They are Depth to water, net Recharge, Aquifer media, Soil media, Topography, Impact of the vadose zone, and hydraulic Conductivity of the aquifer. To arrive at a "DRASTIC" Rating each factor is incorporated into a relative rating scheme that uses a combination of weights and ratings to produce a numerical value. The higher the score an area receives on the index the more vulnerable or susceptible the area is to groundwater pollution. 
Pollution susceptibility means the relative vulnerability of an aquifer to being polluted from spills, discharges, leaks, impoundments, applications of chemicals, injections, and other human activities in the recharge area. 
Pollution susceptibility maps means maps of relative vulnerability to pollution prepared by the Department of Natural Resources, using the "DRASTIC" methodology. Pollution susceptibility maps categorize the land areas of the state into areas having high, medium, and low groundwater pollution potential. 
Recharge area means any portion of the earth's surface, where water infiltrates into the ground to replenish an aquifer. 
Significant recharge area means those areas mapped by the Department of Natural Resources in Hydrologic Atlas 18 (1989 edition). Mapping of recharge areas is based on outcrop area, lithology, soil types and thickness, slope, density of lithologic contacts, geologic structure, the presence of karst, and potentiometric surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 00-19, § B, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-53. - Minimum protection criteria for groundwater recharge areas. 
(a)  New aboveground chemical or petroleum storage tanks, having a minimum volume of 660 gallons, shall have secondary containment for 110 percent of the volume of such tanks or 110 percent of the volume of the largest tank in a cluster of tanks. Such tanks used for agricultural purposes are exempt, provided they comply with all federal requirements. 
(b)  New agricultural waste impoundment sites shall be lined if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area and exceed 15 acre-feet in size and if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area and exceed 50 acre-feet in size. As a minimum, the liner shall be constructed of compacted clay having a thickness of one-foot and a vertical hydraulic conductivity of less than 5 * 10 7 cm/sec or other criteria established by the U.S. Soil Conservation Service. 
(c)  New homes served by septic tanks/drain field systems shall be on lots having the following minimum size limitations as identified on Table MT-1 of the Department of Human Resources "Manual For On-Site Sewage Management Systems." (DHR Table MT-1) 
(1)  125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area. (DRASTIC Rating of 141 to 181) 
(2)  110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (DRASTIC Rating of less than 141) 
(d)  New mobile home parks served by septic tank/drain field systems shall have lots or spaces having the following size limitations as identified on Table MT-2 of the Department of Human Resources "Manual For On-Site Sewage Management Systems." (DHR Table MT-2) 
(1)  125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size of DHR Table MT-2 if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area. (DRASTIC Rating of 141 to 181) 
(2)  110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size of DHR Table MT-2 if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (DRASTIC Rating of less than 141) 
(e)  The Columbus Consolidated Government may exempt existing lots of record from the minimum lot size requirements of subsection (c) for homes and subsection (d) for mobile homes. 
(f)  If the Columbus Zoning Ordinance requires a larger lot size than that required by subsection (c) for homes or subsection (d) for mobile homes, the larger lot size shall be used. 
(g)  No construction may proceed on a building or mobile home to be served by a septic tank unless the Columbus Health Department first approves the proposed septic tank installation as meeting the standards of the DHR manual and minimum lot size requirements. 
(h)  New facilities which handle hazardous materials of the types listed in Section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (excluding underground storage tanks) and in amounts of 10,000 pounds or more on any one day shall perform their operations on impervious surfaces and in conformance with any applicable federal spill prevention requirements and any local fire prevention code requirements. 
(i)  The Columbus Consolidated Government having jurisdictional authority over all significant recharge areas within its boundaries shall adopt, implement, and enforce said ordinance meeting the minimum groundwater protection standards developed by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources and adopted as required environmental criteria by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs. 
(Ord. No. 00-19, § C, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-54. - Groundwater recharge protected areas overlay district map. 
The official map shall be known as the "groundwater recharge protected areas overlay district map" and is attached as part of this article (Map A). 
(Ord. No. 00-19, 2-15-00) 
Editor's note— The groundwater recharge protected areas overlay district map referenced in § 10B-54 above has not been included within this Code, but may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Secs. 10B-55—10B-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SUPPLY WATERSHED PROTECTION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 00-20, adopted Feb. 15, 2000, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as Art. IV, §§ 10B-71—10B-74, of this chapter was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 10B-71. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to insure the protection of the drinking water supply in Columbus and Muscogee County. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § A, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-72. - Definitions. 
The following definitions are terminology used by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources in developing the minimum protection criteria for water supply watersheds. 
Buffer means a natural or enhanced vegetated area with no or limited minor land disturbances, such as trails and picnic areas. Specific buffer uses may be defined by local governments consistent with these criteria. 
Corridor means all land within the buffer areas and other setback areas specified in these criteria. 
Impervious surface means a man-made structure or surface which prevents the infiltration of storm water into the ground below the structure or surface. Examples are buildings, roads, driveways, parking lots, decks, swimming pools, or patios. 
Perennial stream means a stream which flows throughout the whole year as indicated on a USGS Quad map. 
Reservoir boundary means the edge of a water supply reservoir defined by its normal pool level. 
Utility means public or private water or sewer piping systems, water or sewer pumping stations, electric power lines, fuel pipelines, telephone lines, roads, driveways, bridges, river/lake access facilities, storm water systems, and railroads or other utilities identified by local governments. 
Water supply reservoir means a governmentally owned impoundment of water for the primary purpose of providing water to one or more governmentally owned public drinking water systems. This excludes the multipurpose reservoirs owned by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. 
Water supply watershed means the area of land upstream of a governmentally owned public drinking water intake. 
Water supply watershed protection plan means a land use plan prepared and adopted by local governments for the protection of the quality of drinking water obtained from the watershed. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § A, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-73. - Minimum protection criteria for water supply watersheds. 
New hazardous waste facilities (as defined by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq.) within the jurisdictional boundary of Columbus/Muscogee County which are located within a seven-mile radius of the Lake Oliver water supply reservoir/water supply intake point shall be located and perform their operations on impermeable/impervious surfaces having a spill and leak collection system. This article specifically refers to facilities which handle hazardous materials of the types and amounts (10,000 pounds or more on any one day) listed in Section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, excluding underground storage tanks. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § C, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 10B-74. - Water supply watershed protected areas overlay district map. 
The official map shall be known as the "water supply watershed protected areas overlay district map" and is attached as part of this article (Map B). 
(Ord. No. 00-20, 2-15-00) 
Editor's note— The water supply watershed protected areas overlay district map referenced in § 10B-74 above has not been included within this Code, but may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Secs. 10B-75—10B-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MANDATORY RESTRICTION OF OUTDOOR WATER USE 

Sec. 10B-91. - Mandatory restriction of outdoor water use for landscaping. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7, outdoor watering for the purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may only occur between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(a)  Commercial agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A § 1-3-3; 
(b)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; 
(c)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(d)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(e)  Irrigation of personal food gardens; 
(f)  Irrigation of new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(g)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(h)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(i)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(j)  Irrigation of horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(k)  Irrigation of athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(l)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; 
(m)  Hydroseeding. 
(Ord. No. 10-64, § 1, 12-14-10) 
Sec. 10B-92. - Enforcement. 
All persons shall comply with water use restrictions as imposed by the Georgia Water Stewardship Law and any variances thereto. Any water use by any person contrary to the provisions of the restrictions imposed by the Georgia Water Stewardship Law and any variance thereto is a violation of this article. 
The Columbus Board of Water Commissioners shall be the enforcement authority for this article. Violators of this article shall be subject to the following schedule of administrative penalties, which said board shall have the right to change, modify or alter as it deems appropriate and necessary to enforce this Ordinance, to the extent that violations occur within a 12-month period: 
(1)  First violation. Written notice with a description left at the property where the violation occurred. 
(2)  Second violation. $25.00 administrative penalty added to the water bill of the customer's property where the violation occurred. 
(3)  Third violation. $50.00 administrative penalty added to the water bill of the customer's property where the violation occurred. 
(4)  Fourth and subsequent violations. $100.00 administrative penalty added to the water bill of the customer's property where the violation occurred and service termination, plus applicable reconnection of service charges. 
(Ord. No. 10-64, § 2, 12-14-10) 
Sec. 10B-93. - Conflict. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 10-64, § 2, 12-14-10) 
Chapter 11 - FIRE PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Numbering of residences, buildings receiving fire calls, § 18-53. 
State Law reference— As to furnishing the water for the extinguishing of fires by canal companies, see Ga. Code, § 17-109; as to destruction of property to prevent an extension of fires, see § 88-401; as to fire control in forests, see § 43-206; as to abatement of rent on destruction by fire of rented property, see § 61-113; as to requirements for fire escapes in hotels, see §§ 52-205, 52-9902 and in school buildings, see § 32-2001, 32-2002, 32-2003. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Fire safety standards. 
(a)  Adopted. Those certain rules and regulations adopted by the safety fire commissioner as set forth in Chapter 92A-7 of the Georgia Code Annotated are hereby adopted as rules and regulations pertaining to certain buildings for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of said act. 
(b)  Enforcement—Generally. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the chief of the inspections and code enforcement division of Columbus, Georgia. 
(c)  Same—Assistance. The fire marshal of Columbus, Georgia, shall assist the chief of the inspections and code enforcement division in the enforcement of these regulations, and he shall make inspections of existing buildings and structures and shall be responsible for investigating all cases of arson and other suspected incendiary fires. 
(d)  Penalty for violation. Any person, firm, corporation or agent who shall violate a provision of this section shall be guilty of an offense, punishable as set forth in section 1-8 of this Code. Each day's violation of a provision of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Res. of 2-21-50, § 1; Ord. No. 82-27, §§ 1—4, 4-13-82; Ord. No. 83-62, § 1, 7-26-83) 
Cross reference— In connection with the provisions of this article see also Art. IV of this chapter. Fire Prevention Code; fire precautions at airports, § 7-13; discharging firearms or fireworks on the streets of the city, § 14-21; tampering with fire alarm box, § 14-23. 
Sec. 11-2. - Local fire marshal—Submitting name for appointment. 
Some person shall be selected, and the name submitted to the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, as the city's recommendation for appointment as local fire marshal for the city. 
(Res. of 2-21-50, § 2) 
Sec. 11-3. - Same—Co-operation with officials. 
The local fire marshal for the city, when appointed, together with all other city officials, department heads, and employees shall lend their co-operation to the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, state fire marshal and his deputies or assistants, whenever called upon by him or them in the enforcement of the Georgia Safety Fire Law and the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(Res. of 2-21-50, § 3) 
Sec. 11-4. - Resolution, submitting copy to state safety fire commissioner. 
The city clerk shall forward a certified copy of the resolution from which this and the preceding three sections are derived to the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, State Capitol, Atlanta, Georgia. 
(Res. of 2-21-50, § 4) 
Sec. 11-5. - Ashes and combustible material, storage, removal, inspection of premises—Inside buildings. 
(a)  Ashes. No person shall be permitted to place within any building in the city ashes in any box, barrel or other wooden vessel or floor, unless the same is immediately removed from the building, and all owners or occupants of buildings in this city are required to allow the chief of the fire department or any officer or member of the police force to inspect their buildings to see if the above is complied with. 
(b)  Trash, combustible material. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place and let remain in any box, barrel or otherwise in any building, cellar, alleyway, or yard, within the fire limits, for a longer period of time than 18 hours, any loose straw, hay, paper, other combustible matter, and all owners or occupants of buildings or cellars within said limits are hereby required to have an open alleyway extending from one end of the cellar to the other and to permit the chief of the fire department or any member thereof designated by him or any officer or member of the police force, to inspect their buildings, cellars and premises to see whether or not the provisions of this section are being complied with. 
(Code 1914, §§ 393, 693) 
Cross reference— Prohibition against littering streets, § 18-15; sanitary regulations at airports, § 7-7. 
Sec. 11-6. - Same—Outside buildings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow combustible trash, such as boxes, loose straw, paper and any such like material to accumulate on the premises adjoining or near any building within the city. When any such accumulation of combustible material shall be found so as to endanger any building, it shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department or any member of the police force to direct the owner or occupant of such premises to remove the same, and if same shall not be done within a reasonable time, not to exceed three days, upon conviction in the recorder's court of such failure or refusal and of the fact of the existing of such unlawful and dangerous combustible material, such person so convicted shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1914, § 741) 
Sec. 11-6.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 77-109, § 1, enacted Aug. 9, 1977, repealed, § 11-6.1, derived from Ord. No. 71-103, §§1—3, adopted May 18, 1971. Said section prohibited self-service motor fuel businesses as injurious and dangerous to the health and welfare of the residents of the city. 
Sec. 11-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03-76, § 19, adopted September 16, 2003, deleted former § 11-7, which pertained to cause of fires, investigation into, and report, and which derived from § 394 of the 1914 Code. 
Sec. 11-7.1. - Fire district. 
The fire district for Columbus, Georgia, shall include the following areas, as defined herein: 
(a)  Beginning at the west line of Tenth Street and Front Avenue and continuing along Front Avenue in a northerly direction to the western intersection of Front Avenue and Fourteenth Street; thence one block easterly along Fourteenth Street to a point at the intersection of Broadway and Fourteenth Street; thence northerly along Broadway to the western intersection of Fifteenth Street and Broadway; thence easterly along the north side of Fifteenth Street to a point intersecting the western side of Sixth Avenue; thence southerly along the western line of Sixth Avenue to a point intersecting Tenth Street and Sixth Avenue, thence westerly along the south side of Tenth Street to the point of beginning. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 91-87, 9-24-91; Ord. No. 10-61, § 1, 11-30-10) 
Cross reference— Buildings, Ch. 8. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2]
