Sec. 14-11.5. - Burglar alarms. 
(A)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section: 
(1)  Alarm systems means an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion into a premise or to signal an attempted robbery at a protected premise, and with respect to such signal public police are expected to respond. 
(2)  False alarm means the activation of a burglary and/or robbery alarm by other than a forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no burglary, robbery, or forcible entry is being committed or attempted on the premises, and shall include negligently activated alarms; alarms which are the result of equipment which has been improperly installed or maintained; and alarms which are purposely activated to summon the police in nonemergency situations; but does not include an alarm caused by violent conditions of nature or other causes which are beyond the alarm user's or alarm business' control. 
(3)  Response means the dispatch of a police officer to the premises when an alarm system has been activated indicating a burglary and/or robbery is presently in progress on those premises. 
(B)  Prohibitions and restrictions. 
(1)  (a)  It shall be unlawful to maintain on any premises within the city, a burglar alarm system unless the person owning, operating or residing in the location where such alarm is installed has filed with the police department the names, addresses, and phone numbers of at least two parties to be notified that the alarm system is alarming. 
(b)  All commercial premises employing any alarm system shall post at the main entrance a prominent conspicuous notice of an alarm company representative who can be notified at any time and who is authorized to enter the premises and deactivate the system or who can contact a person who can deactivate the system. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to activate any alarm system for the purpose of summoning the police except in the event of an actual or attempted burglary or robbery, or for anyone to fail to notify the police that the alarm was false when that person has knowledge that such activation was a false alarm. 
(C)  Fees. For a police response to any false alarm, the chief of police shall cause to be collected by the finance department from the owner, operator or resident of the premises having such an alarm system fees as follows: 
(1)  After having received notice that an alarm is activated and alarming, the police department shall notify the parties in the order requested by the owner, operator or resident of the premises. In the event the alarm is still activated and alarming 30 minutes after notification, or in the event the police department is unable to reach the parties to be notified, the owner, operator or resident of the premises shall be charged with violation of this section, and the police department shall call a professional alarm service company and have such company to deactivate and turn off the alarm. The police department shall be billed and pay for the service of deactivating the alarm, and the city shall then bill the owner, operator or resident of the premises. The bill submitted to the chief of police by the alarm service company must be submitted within seven days after the service is performed. 
(2)  Upon a fourth response to a false alarm at the same premises within a calendar year, the owner, operator or resident shall be notified by the finance department that any further false alarms within the same calendar year will result in a $25.00 fee being charged for each false alarm. 
(3)  (a) After a fourth response to a false alarm within a calendar year and for all succeeding responses within that calendar year, a fee of $25.00 shall be charged in addition to the service charge set forth in (C)(1) above if applicable. 
(b) The chief of police shall provide the finance department with a bi-monthly report of all false alarms responded to by the police department, and the finance department shall process, bill and collect all fees set forth in this section. 
(D)  Penalties. Any person or business violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be summoned to the recorder's court for each violation and noncompliance and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided by section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-114, § 1, 10-14-80; Ord. No. 92-28, 6-2-92) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 80-114, adopted Oct. 14, 1980, repealed former § 14-11.5 in its entirety and enacted, in lieu thereof, a new § 14-11.5 as herein set forth. The repealed provisions derived from Ord. No. 72-192, § 1, adopted Oct. 3, 1972, also pertained to burglar alarms. 
Sec. 14-11.6. - Business to furnish to chief of police names of persons to call in emergency situations. 
(a)  Names of two persons required. All businesses operating within the confines of Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, having a permanent or leased premises, shall furnish to the chief of police the names, addresses, and phone numbers of two persons who may be reached in the event of an emergency by the police department. 
(b)  Issuance of code numbers. The chief of police shall issue a code number to said business which shall be posted on the front door of the business. Said code number shall allow the police department to maintain in its communications section the names of the individuals who will be notified in the event of an emergency. 
(c)  Compliance by existing businesses. All businesses currently operating in Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, shall have 90 days from the effective date of this section to comply with its provisions. 
(d)  Compliance by new businesses. All new businesses which begin operation after the effective date of this section, shall comply with the section as a condition precedent to the issuance of a business license. 
(e)  Cessation of business. Any person who shall cease operating the business for which a code number has been issued shall notify the chief of police in writing within ten days of ceasing business. 
(f)  Persons responsible for compliance. 
(1)  It shall be the responsibility of the president of a corporation, which is domiciled in Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, to comply with this section. 
(2)  If a foreign corporation not domiciled in Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, operates in Columbus, Georgia, it shall be the responsibility of its local manager to comply with this section. 
(3)  In all other cases, the owner of the business shall furnish the information required under this section. 
(g)  Penalty for violation. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 80-107, §§ 1—7, 9-2-80) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 80-107, enacted Sept. 2, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ 1—7 of said ordinance as § 14-11.6 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Business licenses, § 19-36 et seq. 
Sec. 14-12. - Cross, symbol, etc.; burning, placing, painting; consent required. 
(a)  Burning, on private property. It shall be unlawful for any persons to set fire to or burn, or attempt to set fire to or burn, or assist in setting fire to or burning, any cross, symbol or emblem upon private property owned or occupied by another within the city or its police district, unless the person so committing, or attempting to commit, or assisting in committing any such act secures, in advance, the consent so to do of all the owners and occupants of such property. 
(b)  Placing, on private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or install, or attempt to place or install, or to assist in placing or installing, any cross, symbol or emblem upon private property owned or occupied by another, unless the person so committing, or attempting to commit, or assisting in committing any such act secures, in advance, the consent so to do of all the owners and occupants of such property. 
(c)  Burning, on public property. It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to or burn, or attempt to set fire to or burn, or assist in setting fire to or burning any cross, symbol or emblem in the public streets, roads, or other public places. 
(d)  Painting, on private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, mark, place or install, or attempt so to do, or assist in so doing, upon private property owned or occupied by another, any mark, writing, sign, cross, symbol or emblem, upon private property owned or occupied by another, unless the person so committing, or attempting to commit, or assisting in committing any such act secures, in advance, the consent so to do of all the owners and occupants of such property. 
(e)  Painting, on public property. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, mark, place or install, or attempt so to do, or assist in so doing, in the public streets, roads or other public places, any mark, writing, sign, cross, symbol or emblem, unless the person so committing, or attempting to commit, or assisting in so committing any such act is permitted so to do by ordinance or action of the governmental authority in charge of such public streets, roads, or public places. 
Where a person is on trial for violation of this section, the burden shall be upon him to establish that he has secured the consent required hereby. 
(Ord. of 3-8-49, §§ 1—7) 
Sec. 14-13. - Camping; with vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to camp with his trailer, cart or wagon within the corporate limits of the city except upon the trailer camps or wagon yards set apart for that purpose; it shall be the duty of the chief of police to order all persons violating this section to remove beyond said limits or to such trailer camps or wagon yards. 
(Code 1914, § 783)

Sec. 14-21. - Firearms, fireworks, fires; discharging, lighting on streets, lots, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fire any gun or pistol in any of the streets or sidewalks of the city, or in any of the lots thereof, nor set off any firecrackers or other fireworks nor make any fire in any of the streets or sidewalks thereof, unless by permission of the chief of police; provided, however, this section shall not apply to military companies upon parade, nor be in force upon such public holidays as the commission may from time to time designate, nor to any city officer in the discharge of his official duties. 
(b)  The provisions of this section of the Code of Ordinances of Columbus, Georgia, shall not apply where permission for the discharge of such firearm has been given to the person discharging same by the owner of the property on which said firearm is discharged, and the firing is so controlled that no bullet, projectile or any matter so discharged shall cross the property line of the person granting such permission, and provided further, that no such firearm shall be fired within 300 feet of a private residence or any other building occupied by a person or persons, other than a residence or other building which is located on the property on which the firearm is discharged. 
(Code 1914, § 723; Ord. No. 71-99, § 1, 4-27-71) 
Sec. 14-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 14-22, which pertained to fire alarms and derived from Ord. No. 92-48, adopted June 16, 1992, was deleted as being superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 93-63, included herein as § 14-23. 
Sec. 14-23. - Police, fire and medical alarms. 
(a)  Alarm registration. 
(1)  Alarm registration requires the registration of all types of fire alarms, medical alarms, burglary and other types of alarms being operated in Columbus, Georgia. All alarms which directly or indirectly require the notification of or a response from the 911 Center must be registered. This is applicable to private alarms, commercial alarms or alarms monitored by an alarm service. Although an alarm may be monitored by an out-of-town company it must be registered on properties located in Columbus, Georgia. 
(2)  Alarms will be registered in the finance department of the city government. An application must be completed listing required alarm information. Upon completion of the necessary paperwork the applicant will be issued an alarm permit with a unique number. The alarm information will be entered into a data base and associated with the unique number on the alarm permit. The initial alarm registration period will run from October 1, 1993-December 1, 1993, the alarm permit will be valid for calendar year 1994. Alarm permits must be renewed annually between October 1 and December 31. The alarm registration program and the issuance of an alarm permit will be provided to applicants free of charge. 
(3)  A minimum fee of $30.00 will be assessed for failure to register an alarm, operating an alarm without a permit or operating an alarm with an invalid permit within the City of Columbus, Georgia. 
(4)  The permit must be displayed in a prominent location on or near the front entrance to the premises where it can be seen by responding units. 
(5)  The permit is not transferable. 
(6)  The permit must be displayed at the premises (address) listed on the application or it is not valid. 
(7)  If the home or business is sold, the permit holder must cancel the permit by notifying the finance department of the city government. 
(8)  Permits will not be required for motor vehicle alarms. 
(b)  Definitions. (For the purposes of this section): 
(1)  Alarm systems means an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect and signal a fire, medical emergency, burglary or other types of response in a premise, and with respect to which public firefighters, emergency medical service personnel or police officers are expected to respond. 
(2)  False alarm means any untrue report of fire, medical emergency or police response given to the 911 Center by telephone or messenger or by use of an alarm signal box; or the activation of an alarm system, and shall include negligently activated alarms, alarms which are the result of equipment which has been improperly installed or maintained, and alarms which are purposely activated to summon the public safety personnel in nonemergency situations, but does not include an alarm caused by violent conditions of nature. 
(3)  Response means the dispatch of any fire department, ambulance equipment or police personnel to the premises when an alarm system has been activated indicating a fire, medical or police emergency is presently in progress on those premises. 
(c)  Maliciously give or cause to be given false alarm; breaking or injuring alarm prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously give or cause to be given any false alarm; or to break or cause to be broken or in any manner injure, cut or damage or cause to be injured, cut, or damaged any publicly owned fire alarm signal boxes, poles, wires, or other apparatus, or to in any manner interfere with the same, or any part thereof, or the working of the same, or any part thereof, unless by the consent of or under the supervision of the fire chief. 
(d)  Activation of false alarm prohibited. It shall be unlawful for anyone to activate any alarm system for the purpose of summoning the fire department, emergency medical service or police department except in the event of an actual fire, medical or police emergency, or for anyone to fail to notify the fire department, emergency medical services or police department that the alarm was false when that person has knowledge that such activation was a false alarm. 
(e)  Fees. For a response to any false alarm, the fire chief, EMS chief or police chief shall cause to be collected by the finance department from the owner, business operator or resident of the premises having such an alarm system fees as follows: 
(1)  Upon a fourth response individually to a fire, EMS, police or other type of false alarm at the same premises within a calendar year, the owner, business operator or resident shall be notified by the finance department that any further false alarms within the same calendar year will result in a $150.00 fee for fire false alarms, $100.00 fee for emergency medical services false alarms and $25.00 fee for police and other types of false alarms. 
(2)  The fire chief, emergency medical services chief and chief of police shall provide the finance department with a bimonthly report of all false alarms responded to by the fire department, emergency medical services and police department, the finance department shall process, bill and collect all fees set forth in this section. 
(f)  Penalties. Any person or business violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this ordinance, and failing to pay any fee charged pursuant to this section within 90 days of the false alarm for which the fee is charged, shall be summoned to the Recorder's Court for each violation or instance of noncompliance and, upon conviction, shall be subject to the provisions of section 1-8 of the Columbus Code. 
(Ord. No. 93-63, 7-20-93)

(b)  Any person violating this section, or any part thereof, shall, upon conviction before the recorder of the City of Columbus, be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code.

Sec. 14-28. - Hats; wearing in theaters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to wear a hat or any other covering of the head which obstructs the view of other persons, in any theater, opera house, motion picture theater or any other building where an entertainment is given and an admission charged, during any performance at such theater, opera house, motion picture theater or any other building where an entertainment is given and an admission charged. 
It shall be unlawful for any proprietor, manager, or any other person in charge of any theater, opera house, motion picture theater, or any other building where an entertainment is given and an admission is charged to permit any person to wear a hat, or any other covering of the head which obstructs the view of other persons in any theater, opera house, motion picture theater or any other building where an entertainment is given and an admission charged. 
(Code 1914, §§ 665, 666) 
Sec. 14-29. - Iceboxes, refrigerators, etc., safety precautions. 
It shall be unlawful to own, maintain, harbor, keep, possess or permit on one's premises any icebox, refrigerator, ice chest, deep freeze unit or cold storage vault or chest, equipped with a device which automatically locks it when the door is closed, unless the same is actually being used indoors for the purpose for which it was intended. 
The provisions of this section shall not apply to the owning, maintaining, harboring, keeping, possessing or permitting on one's premises of the items listed in the preceding paragraph hereof, indoors for the purpose of resale in a regularly operated business establishment, or indoors in the regular storage area of a licensed warehouse, storage or transit establishment or facility. 
(Ord. of 11-10-53, §§ 1, 2)

(Code 1914, § 662)

Sec. 14-41. - Junk and scrap metal dealers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any junk shop or junk dealer, or any dealer in scrap metals, and any agents of such businesses, to purchase new copper or brass items or new copper or brass scrap, new or used vehicle or storage batteries, manhole or sewer inlet or water meter covers or any other metal item which originates with any utility installation, or new plumbing supplies or fixtures, without first requiring the seller to provide information to be kept as a written record by the buyer, which shall include a general description of the merchandise and any particular marks or numbers or other characteristics which would help to identify or distinguish the items as well as the time and date it was obtained by the purchaser and from whom it was obtained as well as the make and color of the vehicle in which it was transported and the vehicular license tag number and its state, county and date of issuance. 
(b)  The seller shall be identified by name, address, and telephone number and supporting documents such as a driver's license shall be required, and this information shall be kept in written form along with the information concerning the merchandise and its method of transportation; however, no records need to be kept nor will the provisions of this section apply in any manner to sellers who are licensed commercial or industrial enterprises and who are known by the buyer. 
(c)  Each business required to keep records under the provisions of this section shall retain the recorded items on its premises for a period of seven days after their receipt in unaltered form and in a place readily accessible for inspection by law enforcement officers or the general public. 
(d)  Businesses shall retain the required written information for a period of 90 days, and such information shall bear the signature of the owner or manager or some other agent of the business for each sales transaction. 
(Ord. No. 84-10, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 84-10, enacted Feb. 7, 1984, repealed former § 14-41 and enacted, in lieu thereof, a new § 14-41 as hereinabove set forth. Former § 14-41 pertained to receiving junk from minors and derived from § 1 of an ordinance of May 5, 1915. 
Cross reference— Dealers in secondhand jewelry, precious metals and gems, Ch. 10; secondhand dealers, § 14-81 et seq.; pawnbrokers, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 14-42. - Loitering, loafing, idling. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found idling, standing, loitering or loafing, within the city, or within its police jurisdiction, as follows: 
(1)  In, on, or upon the streets, avenues, lanes, sidewalks, alleyways, viaducts, bridges over the Chattahoochee River, cemeteries, parks, or other public property, school buildings or other public buildings, in such a manner as to impede vehicular or pedestrian traffic or to threaten or to be detrimental to the safety, health, or general welfare of the city or the citizens thereof; 
(2)  In, on or upon pool rooms, saloons, beer halls, cafes, night clubs, or other places where alcoholic, malt or vinous liquors or beverages are lawfully sold, after having been directed by a police officer or by the owner, tenant, or other person in charge of such premises, to leave and vacate such premises; 
(3)  In, or upon any place or establishment used as a disorderly or lewd house; any place or establishment where illegally manufactured or nontax paid alcoholic, malt or vinous liquors or beverages are found, possessed, kept or sold; or any place or establishment where gaming, gambling or lottery laws are violated; 
(4)  In, on or upon railroad yards, rights-of-way, or depots; bus depots; hotels; theaters; places of worship; or other places of private property, whether residence, business or vacant, without the invitation of the owner, tenant or other person in charge of such places; or after having been directed by a police officer or by the owner, tenant or other person in charge of such premises to leave and vacate such premises. 
(5)  On pedestrian overpasses or their approaches. 
(Ord. of 5-25-25, § 1; Ord. of 7-3-56, § 1; Ord. No. 69-33, § 1, 3-17-69; Ord. No. 69-194, § 1, 10-20-69) 
Secs. 14-43—14-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, enacted May 23, 1978, repealed §§ 14-43 and 14-44 derived from Code 1914, § 799, and Ord. of April 27, 1948, §§ 1—3. Said sections pertained to the wearing of masks and public and/or public political meetings. 
Sec. 14-44.1. - Model airplanes, unlawful to fly except in designated areas. 
It shall be unlawful to fly within the city limits of Columbus, Georgia, model airplanes that are propelled by gasoline engines, except in the following described area: 
(a)  Privately owned property where the flight of such planes is confined within the boundary line of the privately owned property. This exception shall be applicable only prior to a complaint having been made to the police department by a person residing in a building the nearest part of which is within 500 feet of the ground over which such planes are flown and notice of such complaint has been given to the private owner by the police department. 
(b)  Property of Columbus, Georgia, north of Macon Road, which lies adjacent to the county morgue. 
(Ord. No. 60-14, § 1, 1-18-60; Ord. No. 60-32, § 1, 3-28-60; Ord. No. 88-114, 11-15-88) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 60-14, did not amend this Code; however, it is included as § 14-44.1, as hereinabove set out, at the editor's discretion. Ord. No. 60-32, amended aforementioned Ord. No. 60-14 by adding the material which the editors in their discretion designated subsection (e) or § 14-44.1. 
Sec. 14-44.2. - Entering unoccupied building without owner's written consent prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to enter an unoccupied house, apartment, part of a house, or other building without the written consent of the owner of the property or the owner's agent. Written consent may be shown by direct written permission, lease, rent receipt, work order, realty listing, or other suitable document which shows that a person has the owner's permission to be on and in the premises. Violators shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of the Columbus, Georgia, Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. of 3-24-32, § 1; Ord. No. 79-44, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 14-45. - Personal floatation devices required on Chattahoochee River between North Highlands Dam and Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center. 
(a)  Personal floatation devices (PFDs) required on Chattahoochee River between North Highlands Dam and the southern property line of the Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, canoe, kayak, raft, jet-ski, or use any other vessel on the Chattahoochee River between the North Highlands Dam and the southern property line of the Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center without wearing a personal floatation device as defined in O.C.G.A. § 52-7-3. 
For purposes of this Code section, "vessel" shall have the meaning set forth in O.C.G.A. § 52-7-3. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall not apply to sanctioned swimming events or competitions where rescue personnel are present. 
(Ord. No. 12-52, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 14-45.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— The former section 14-45.1 was repealed by Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, enacted May 23, 1978. Said section pertained to obscene pictures or literature and derived from Code 1914, § 646; Ord. No. 69-27, §§ 1—3, adopted March 3, 1969; Ord. No. 70-337, § 1, adopted Dec. 14, 1970; and Ord. No. 70-343, § 2, adopted Dec. 21, 1970. 
Sec. 14-46. - Obscene writing, defacing property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to mark in obscene language, cut or otherwise deface any fence, house or tree in the city limits. 
(Code 1914, § 648) 
Sec. 14-47. - Obstructing officer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, resist or oppose the mayor or marshal or any commissioner, policeman, wharfinger, health officer, or other officer of the city in the performance of any duty required of such officer by the laws and ordinances or orders of the city or the authorities thereof. 
(Code 1914, § 639) 
Sec. 14-47.1. - Oliver, Eagle-Phenix, North Highland Dams and Reservoirs; use restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to swim, operate a boat, or otherwise approach upon the impounded waters of the Oliver Dam Reservoir closer than 300 feet of said Oliver Dam. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to swim, operate a boat or otherwise approach the impounded waters of the Eagle-Phenix Dam Reservoir and the North Highland Dam Reservoir closer than 300 feet to such dams. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to approach the North Highland Dam, or Eagle-Phenix Dam, or the Oliver Dam, below said dams closer than 300 feet. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to recreational activities that occur in and beside the Chattahoochee River as part of the creation of the Chattahoochee River Park from the North Highlands Dam to the southern property line of the Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center. 
(Ord. No. 59-60, § 1, 11-10-59; Ord. No. 63-57, §§ 1, 2, 7-1-63; Ord. No. 11-16, § 1, 3-29-11; Ord. No. 12-52, § 2, 12-4-12) 
Cross reference— Speed limits for boats on Chattahoochee River, § 14-11.3. 
Sec. 14-47.2. - Boating speed limits and water skiing on Lake Oliver. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a boat at a greater speed than ten miles per hour within 1,000 feet of the municipal marina dock on Lake Oliver, except in that portion of the water which lies within 100 feet of the north bank of the impounded water, in which excepted portion it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a boat at a greater speed than 20 miles per hour. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to water ski upon the impounded waters of Lake Oliver within 1,000 feet of the municipal marina dock, except in that portion of the water which lies within 100 feet of the north bank of the impounded water. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction before the recorder of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to construction activities that occur in and beside the Chattahoochee River as part of the restoration project to be supervised by the United States Army Corps of Engineers. 
(Ord. No. 60-66, §§ 1—3, 7-18-60; Ord. No. 11-16, § 2, 3-29-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 60-66, §§ 1—3, enacted July 18, 1960, added the provisions codified as § 14-47.2. Since said ordinance did not expressly amend this Code, it has been so codified at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 14-47.3. - Places endangered by rising water; occupying prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy any area in the river surrounded by water on which said person might be entrapped by rising water. The provisions of this section shall not apply to recreational activities that occur in and beside the Chattahoochee River as part of the creation of the Chattahoochee River Park from the North Highlands Dam to the southern property line of the Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center. 
(Ord. No. 63-63, 1-8-63; Ord. No. 11-16, § 3, 3-29-11; Ord. No. 12-52, § 3, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 14-47.4. - Swimming prohibited at Municipal Marina on Lake Oliver. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to go swimming, or to permit a minor in his or her custody or care to go swimming, from the banks, docks or ramps, of the Municipal Marina on Lake Oliver, in the city. 
(Ord. No. 66-157, § 1, 8-1-66) 
Editor's note— Section 14-47.4 is derived from Ord. No. 66-157, adopted August 1, 1966. This ordinance, which was nonamendatory of this Code, was codified in the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 14-47.5. - Swimming prohibited at Municipal Docks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to go swimming or to permit a minor in his or her custody or care to go swimming within 300 feet of any municipal docks south of the southern property line of the Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center. 
(Ord. No. 67-160, 8-21-67; Ord. No. 12-52, § 4, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 14-47.6. - Jumping, diving into water from bridges prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to jump or dive into any of the waters located in Columbus, Georgia from any bridge therein. 
(Ord. No. 74-127, § 1, 7-30-74) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 74-127, § 1, being nonamendatory of this Code, has been included herein as § 14-47.6 at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 14-48. - Police whistle, imitating. 
It shall not be lawful for any person other than police officers, or persons entrusted therewith by the police authorities, to use or blow, within the corporate limits of the city, any echo whistle or police whistle of the kind used by the police force as a police call. 
(Code 1914, § 642) 
Cross reference— Imitating fire whistle, § 14-20. 
Sec. 14-48.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 14-48.1, relative to the escape of prisoners, derived from Ord. No. 69-151, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 18, 1969, was repealed by Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, adopted May 23, 1978. 
Sec. 14-49. - Profanity over telephone. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the operation of any telephone installed within the city, to make use of any vulgar vituperation or profane language into and over such telephone. 
(Code 1914, § 663) 
Sec. 14-50. - Transporting, receiving, aiding persons to engage in prostitution or sodomy. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly transport a person into or within the boundaries of Columbus, Georgia, for the purpose of promoting that person's engagement in prostitution or sodomy. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly receive, offer or agree to receive another into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution or sodomy or knowingly to permit others to remain there for either of such purposes. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly provide money or anything of value to another for the purpose of inducing another to transport a person into or within the boundaries of Columbus, Georgia, for the purpose of promoting that person's engagement in prostitution or sodomy or for the purpose of inducing another to receive a person into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution or sodomy. 
(Ord. of 6-12-19, § 1; Ord. No. 79-29, § 1, 3-20-79) 
Sec. 14-51. - Penalty for violation of section 14-50. 
Whenever any person convicted of a violation of the preceding section shall be licensed under any ordinance or law to operate an automobile or other conveyance for hire, the license shall immediately become void and of no effect, and no license to operate an automobile or other conveyance for hire shall hereafter be granted to such person for a period of one year. 
(Ord. of 6-12-19, § 2) 
Sec. 14-52. - Loitering for purposes of prostitution, sodomy, pimping; definitions for section. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in or near any thoroughfare or place open to the public in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of committing prostitution or sodomy or manifesting the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to purchase sexual intercourse or physical intimacies in an act of prostitution or sodomy. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether these purposes are manifested are that such person is a known prostitute, pimp or sodomist, repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passersby in conversation, or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, waving of arms or any bodily gesture. No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer first affords such person an opportunity to explain this conduct, and no one shall be convicted of violating this subsection if it appears at trial that the explanation given was true and disclosed a lawful purpose. 
(b)  For the purpose of subsection (a), a "known prostitute, pimp or sodomist" is a person who, within one year previous to the date of arrest for violation of this section, has within the knowledge of the arresting officer been convicted of violating any ordinance of any local government or the law of any state defining and punishing any acts of prostitution, pimping, sodomy or related offenses. 
(Code 1914, § 658; Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, 5-23-78; Ord. No. 78-70, § 1, 6-13-78; Ord. No. 79-29, § 2, 3-20-79) 
Sec. 14-53. - Persons suspected of having venereal disease. 
(a)  Categories of suspected persons. A person in any of the following categories may be reasonably suspected to have venereal disease: 
(1)  Any person who is arrested and charged with an offense in the nature of or involving loitering, loitering or entering barrooms by streetwalkers, associating with prostitutes, soliciting for or aiding or transporting prostitutes, prostitution, pimping, pandering, rape, sodomy, or any other crime related to sex and any person convicted of any such offense. 
(2)  Any person with a prior conviction of an offense enumerated in subsection (a)(1) hereof, reasonably suspected to have had contact with another individual reasonably believed to have had a communicable venereal disease at the time of such contact, and any person with a prior conviction of an offense enumerated subsection (a)(1) hereof who is reasonably believed to have transmitted any such disease to another individual. Any person who has had any such disease or who has been convicted of any offense of the kinds specified in subsection (a)(1) within 12 months next past, and who is reasonably believed to be engaged in any activity which might have occasioned exposure to a communicable venereal disease. 
(b)  Detention in jail. Suspected persons in the categories enumerated in subsection (a)(1) hereof may be detained in jail. When any person so detained is determined not to have venereal disease in communicable form the health officer or his authorized deputy shall release the individual from detention for health purposes. The detention of any person in jail under the provisions hereof shall continue only for such time as is reasonably necessary to examine such person and render treatment if such person is found to have a venereal disease in a communicable form. The provisions hereof shall not be utilized as, nor construed to be, a penalty or punishment. No person detained for health purposes under the provisions hereof shall be released from such detention even if he or she is otherwise eligible for release on bond or by reason of payment of fine, or termination of sentence imposed. 
(c)  Examination in jail. Every suspected person detained in jail under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall be examined by the department of public health for the purpose of determining whether or not such person is, in fact, infected with a communicable venereal disease. Every such person shall submit to such examinations as are necessary and permit specimens to be taken for laboratory analyses. The detention of each suspected person shall continue until the results of such examinations are known and the person found to be free from any such disease, or, if infected, until the disease is no longer communicable. 
(d)  Treatment in jail. The department of public health shall treat every person suspected to have venereal disease who has been detained and examined in jail and found to have any such disease. The treatment shall continue until the disease is no longer communicable. 
(e)  Examination and treatment at department or by private physician. Every suspected person in the categories enumerated in subsection (a)(2) of this section who is not detained in jail shall be examined at the department of public health on an inpatient or outpatient basis as determined in individual instances by the health officer or his authorized deputy. Each such person shall submit to examinations as necessary and permit specimens to be taken for laboratory analyses and shall comply with the directions of the health officer or his authorized deputy with relation to hospitalization on an inpatient basis or attendance at the clinic or an outpatient basis, as the case may be. Each such person shall continue to follow these directions until the results of his or her examination are known and the person determined to be free from any such disease, or, if infected, until the disease is no longer communicable. With the consent of the health officer or his authorized deputy a suspected person may be at his or her expense examined by a doctor licensed to practice medicine and treated medically for such disease, if necessary. In these latter instances, the health officer or his authorized deputy shall receive reports of examinations and treatment and other information relative to the problems involved from the medical doctor selected. 
(f)  Authority of police to enforce section provisions. Police officers shall have authority to detain suspected persons in the categories enumerated in subsection (a)(1) for health purposes in jail in accordance with the procedure set forth in subsection (b) for examination and treatment by the department of public health under the provisions of subsections (c) and (d). Police officers shall have authority to order suspected persons in the categories enumerated in subsections (a)(1) and (2) who are not detained in jail to report to the department of public health for examination and treatment at the direction of the health officer or his authorized deputy in accordance with the provisions of subsection (e). They shall also have the authority to order persons to report to the department of public health for examination and treatment, as aforesaid, who have been held for investigation of offenses of the types enumerated in subsection (a)(1) and who have been released without charges having been filed, and similarly persons who have been acquitted of any such charges and other suspected persons who have been released on bond. 
(g)  Violations. It shall be unlawful to refuse to submit to examination or treatment under an order as hereinabove provided or to violate any order of detention or to refuse to obey any order requiring submittal to examination and treatment at the department of public health. It shall be unlawful to refuse to obey any order of the health officer or his authorized deputy issued under the provisions of this section or to refuse to obey any order of a police officer issued under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 79-30, §§ 1—7, 3-20-79) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-30, adopted March 20, 1979, repealed § 14-53 which pertained to association with prostitutes and was derived from Code 1914, § 649. Said ordinance further directed that sections 1—7 thereof be codified herein as a new § 14-53. 
Sec. 14-54. - Railways—Alighting, boarding; while moving. 
It shall be unlawful for any person unconnected with the railroad trains, to get on the engines or cars of a train within the city, unless for the bona fide purpose of taking passage on the same. It shall be unlawful for any person unconnected with the railroad trains to jump on or off a moving train in said city; provided, however, nothing in this section shall be construed so as to interfere with persons meeting friends, or seeing them off on the train of cars, when the same are not in motion. 
(Code 1914, § 664) 
Sec. 14-55. - Same—Persons crossing trestles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cross or attempt to cross any railway trestle or bridge in the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply in any case where the railroad authorities in pursuance of their respective business make use of either of said trestles or bridges. 
(Code 1914, § 753) 
Secs. 14-56, 14-57. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 14-56, relative to building of structures or placing of animal carcasses on the river bank, and § 14-57, prohibiting slandering of the president or country, were repealed by Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, adopted May 23, 1978. Said sections were derived from Code 1914, § 782, and Ord. of June 5, 1918. 
Sec. 14-58. - Slingshots, similar devices. 
It shall be unlawful to shoot gravel, shot or marble, or any other thing out of a gravel shooter, blow gun or marble sling, or other device or implement of like character. 
(Code 1914, § 652) 
Sec. 14-59. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 75-32, § 1, adopted April 15, 1975, repealed § 14-59 regarding slot machines, the prohibition of and types excepted. Said section was derived from Ord. of Jan. 30, 1939, § 1, and Ord. No. 58-89. 
Sec. 14-60. - Steamboats; captain to deliver offenders. 
In case of violation of any of the laws and ordinances of the city, when the offender is on board of any of the boats at the wharf or leaving the same, the commander of such boat shall be required to stop and deliver the offender on being signaled by any officer to do so. 
(Code 1914, § 651) 
Sec. 14-60.1. - Tattooing—Prohibited on persons under 18 without consent of parent or guardian. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individual or firm, to tattoo or mark or color the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form marks or figures or scars on any portion of the body of any individual under the age of 18. This section, however, shall not apply to any minor whose parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of such minor shall in writing consent to such act of tattooing. 
(Ord. No. 57-72, § 1; Ord. No. 76-49, § 1, 5—4-76) 
Sec. 14-60.2. - Same—Prohibited on persons under influence of intoxicating liquor, malt beverages or drugs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individual or firm, to tattoo or mark or color the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form marks or figures or scars on any portion of the body of any individual who is under the influence to any extent of intoxicating liquors, malt beverages or drugs. 
(Ord. No. 57-72, § 2) 
Sec. 14-60.3. - Same—Prohibited on Sunday or Sabbath days. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individual or firm to conduct the business of tattooing or marking or coloring the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form marks or figures or scars on any portion of the body of any individual on Sunday or the Sabbath days. 
(Ord. No. 57-72, § 3) 
Sec. 14-60.4. - Same—Penalty for violation of provisions. 
Any person violating this ordinance [sections 14-60.1 through 14-60.4 of this Code] shall, upon conviction before the recorder of the City of Columbus, be punished as set forth in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 57-72, § 4) 
Sec. 14-61. - Vending candy, etc., near schools; permission required. 
It shall be unlawful for any ice cream, peanut, candy or fruit vendor to sell ice cream, peanuts, candy or fruit within 500 feet of any public school in any street or sidewalk in the city, or to take any stand for the purpose of selling such merchandise within 500 feet of any public school without first obtaining permission from the principal of such public school. 
(Ord. No. 9-7-21, § 1) 
Sec. 14-62. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 78-70, § 1, enacted June 13, 1978, repealed § 14-62, relative to running wires over roofs of houses, derived from Code 1914, § 785. 
Sec. 14-62.1. - Smoking on buses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person riding the buses of the Columbus Transit System (METRA) to smoke tobacco or any similar substance in any fashion or form. 
(b)  Appropriate signs shall be erected in all buses. 
(Ord. No. 88-15, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-88) 
Editor's note— Former § 14-62.1 was deleted as being superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 88-15, adopted Feb. 16, 1988, which did not specifically amend the Code. The deleted provisions pertained to "no smoking" areas on city buses and derived from Ord. No. 76-115, §§ 1—3, adopted Aug. 17, 1976. 
Sec. 14-62.2. - Disorderly conduct generally. 
(a)  A person may be charged with, and convicted of, the offense of disorderly conduct when such person commits any of the following acts: 
(1)  Performs an unlawful act of violence or performs any other act in such a violent and tumultuous manner that the public peace and tranquility is disturbed; 
(2)  Verbally or physically harasses, menaces, or intimidates a person to the disturbance of the public peace; 
(3)  Engages in a fight in public which is not a part of an authorized exhibition; 
(4)  Recklessly or knowingly commits an act which may reasonably be expected to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, gathering, or procession; 
(5)  Without provocation, uses to, or of another, in that person's presence, opprobrious, abusive, or obscene words which by their very utterance tend to incite a person to an immediate breach of the peace; 
(6)  Enters upon the grounds of any school, with no lawful business there, and remains there to the disturbance and disruption of the school and its activities; 
(7)  Exhibits oneself in public in an indecent or lewd manner to the disturbance of the public peace and tranquility; 
(8)  Is in a public place or, without permission or invitation, upon the property of another, in a state of drunkenness exemplified by boisterous, vulgar, profane, or loud language, or by indecent personal condition, or by indecent act. 
(b)  A person convicted of disorderly conduct by reason of committing one of the preceding acts shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Columbus, Georgia Code. 
(Ord. No. 78-73, §§ 1, 2, 6-20-78) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 78-73 amended this Code, but did not specify the manner of amendment, hence inclusion of §§ 1, 2 herein as § 14-62.2 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 14-62.3. - Billiard rooms and tables regulated. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority of Georgia Laws 1978, pages 1488, 1489 and 1490, and the home rule authority granted to this government by Georgia law, billiard rooms and tables are hereby subject to licensing and regulation by Columbus, Georgia. None of the laws found in Georgia Code Annotated, Chapter 84-16 as the chapter exists, or is hereafter amended, shall apply to billiard rooms and tables. 
(b)  The licensing and regulation permitted to Columbus, Georgia previously by state law is hereby reaffirmed. 
(c)  Billiard rooms and tables shall be licensed as provided by Columbus, Georgia Code, section 19-47, Code No. 1120. 
(d)  If any billiard room is physically connected with an establishment that has an on-premise alcoholic beverage license of any type, or if any billiard table is located in such establishment, then the hours of operation of such billiard room or billiard table shall be the same as those permitted for the establishment under the alcoholic beverage control laws of Columbus, Georgia, and the State of Georgia. Any other rules and laws pertaining to such establishments by virtue of their sale of alcoholic beverages, such as the entry of minors into such establishments, shall apply to the billiard room connected with such establishment or to such table. 
(e)  If the billiard room or game room shall not be so physically connected with an establishment with an on-premise alcoholic beverage license or any type, or if any table shall not be so located, the foregoing provisions shall not apply. 
(f)  No billiard room shall have any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other obstructions which prevent a clear view of the interior. No interior partitions except those for closets, toilet rooms, or wash rooms shall be permitted. 
(g)  No games of chance or any form of gambling whatsoever shall be permitted or allowed in any billiard room or other establishment containing a billiard table or tables. This shall include any gambling based on the playing of games on the billiards tables. 
(h)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to billiard rooms or billiard tables operated by private industrial concerns, philanthropic or religious associations, religious orders, charitable institutions, institutions of the State or of Columbus, Georgia, fraternal orders, or bona fide clubs using such billiard rooms or tables for members, residents, or employees only. 
(i)  Any violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Columbus, Georgia Code. 
(Ord. No. 78-89, §§ 1—9, 7-25-78; Ord. No. 81-118, § 1, 10-6-81) 
Sec. 14-62.4. - Injury to, destruction of apparatus used in supplying public services. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp or other apparatus belonging to any company or Columbus, Georgia, engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone or other public services, or intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied, or in any way to interfere with the proper action of such company or Columbus, Georgia, intentionally to divert any services of such company or Columbus, Georgia or otherwise intentionally and without authority to use or cause to be used, without the consent of such company or Columbus, Georgia, any service manufactured, sold or distributed by such company or Columbus, Georgia. 
(b)  Proof that a person performed any of the acts set forth in subsection (a), or proof that a person knowingly received the benefit of such acts, or proof that any of the acts specified in subsection (a) were done on premises in possession of a person, with that person's knowledge, shall be prima facie evidence that such person or persons are responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. 
(c)  Violators of the foregoing provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Columbus, Georgia Code. 
(Ord. No. 78-91, §§ 1—3, 7-25-78) 
Editor's note— Section 14-62.4 is derived from Ord. No. 78-91 which ordinance amended Ch. 14 by adding the provisions included herein as § 14-62.4. 
Sec. 14-62.5. - Issuing identification cards prohibited; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to issue to another person any identification card containing a description of the person or such person's photograph or such person's birthdate or such person's social security number, or any such similar information purporting to be the identifying factors of such person carrying said card, unless such identification card is issued by a governmental agency or unless such identification card is issued by an employer for the purpose of identifying its employees or unless such identification card is issued by clubs or organizations for the purpose of identifying their members. 
(Ord. No. 85-41, 4-9-85) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 85-41, enacted April 9, 1985, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of such ordinance as § 14-62.5 is at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE II. - WEAPONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Types of weapons which pawnbrokers are not allowed to receive or sell or have in their possession, §§ 15-8, 15-9, 15-10; pistol, rifle prohibited on boat, § 14-11.2. 

Sec. 14-63. - Sale of pistols, cartridges—Record, inspection. 
All persons doing business in the city or its police district who sell or dispense pistol or pistol cartridges shall at all times keep in their places of business complete lists and descriptions of all pistols and pistol cartridges kept, sold or delivered by them, and the names and addresses of persons to whom sold or delivered, which lists shall be open to inspection at all times by members of the police department of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-10-49, § 1) 
Sec. 14-64. - Same—Notice; investigation; approval; waiting period. 
No person doing business in the city or its police district shall sell or deliver any pistol or pistol cartridges until all of the following regulations have been complied with strictly: 
Before selling or delivering any pistol or pistol cartridges, such dealer shall notify, in writing, the chief of police, in such notice giving the name, address and description of the prospective purchaser. The prospective purchaser shall, at the same time, furnish to the chief of police three written and signed testimonials vouching for the general good character of the prospective purchaser, and such prospective purchaser shall also submit to having his fingerprints taken by the police department of the city. The chief of police shall make full investigation, and should he, in his discretion, find that the prospective purchaser is of good moral character, and that such pistol or cartridges are desired for legal and purely defensive purposes only, he shall approve the sale; but if, on the other hand, the chief of police should find that the prospective purchaser is not of good moral character, or that the pistol or cartridges are desired for illegal purposes, or for other than purely defensive purposes, he shall disapprove the proposed sale, and when so disapproved, it shall be unlawful for any such dealer to sell or deliver such pistol or cartridges to the prospective purchaser. In the absence of the chief of police, his duties and discretion hereunder shall be performed and exercised by the officer of the police department in charge of such department during the absence of the chief. 
No pistol or pistol cartridges shall be sold or delivered by any such dealer until the period of five days shall have elapsed after the service on the chief of police of the notice of the proposed sale. 
(Ord. of 5-10-49, § 2) 
Sec. 14-64.1. - Control of sale of handguns; certificate required; handgun purchaser identification card for multiple purchases; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell or otherwise convey any handgun to any individual without a certificate from the chief of police, or his designee, stating that to the best of his knowledge the applicant is free of felony convictions. If said applicant is found to be free of felony convictions, the chief of police, or his designee must by law furnish applicant with such certificate at the end of three days from the date application is made. Under no circumstances is the chief of police, or his designee, to deny such certificate to any person at any time other than for reason of prior felony conviction. 
For those applicants who make multiple handgun purchases during the course of the year, a handgun purchasers identification card shall be made available. This card shall exempt holder from the necessity of obtaining a certificate for each handgun purchased. Said card shall be available from the city license section upon receipt of a certificate from the chief of police, or his designee, stating that to the best of his knowledge the applicant is free of felony convictions. The card shall contain a physical description and picture of the holder and expense of issuance shall be borne by an issuance fee of $3.00. The card shall be valid for a period of three years from date of issuance. In the event any holder of a valid handgun purchasers identification is convicted of a felony, such identification shall immediately be revoked by the chief of police. 
(b)  Dealers selling handguns may submit application to the chief of police or his designee on behalf of the prospective purchaser, and the chief of police or his designee may return the certificate directly to the seller submitting the application. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) above, upon payment of a $5.00 processing fee by such a seller at the time an application is submitted, the chief of police or his designee shall return the certificate directly to the seller submitting the application on the date that the application is submitted. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) above, dealers or collectors selling handguns at gun shows may, upon payment of a $5.00 processing fee, submit application to the chief of police or his designee on behalf of the prospective purchaser, and the chief of police or his designee shall return the certificate directly to the dealer or collector submitting the application on the date that the application is submitted. 
(c)  Provided, however, that the terms of this section shall not apply to dealers holding federal firearms license when purchasing handguns. Provided further, that the terms of this section shall not apply to the disposition of gun collections by executors or administrators of estates. 
(Ord. No. 75-14, § 1, 2-25-75; Ord. No. 75-23, § 1, 3-25-75; Ord. No. 75-31, § 1, 4-15-75; Ord. No. 78-44, § 1, 5-2-78; Ord. No. 88-121, §§ 1, 2, 12-13-88) 
Sec. 14-65. - Dangerous weapons; prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall within the city or its police district, sell, exchange or keep on hand for the purpose of sale any of the following named articles: Shotgun or rifle with barrel length of less than 18 inches, knucks, dirk, sword-cane, blackjack, Bowie-knife, spring-back knife, switch-blade knife, or any knife with a blade exceeding four inches in length; but it is not the intention hereof to prohibit case knives, butcher knives or other knives customarily used for domestic or industrial purposes only. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wear or carry any pistol, dirk-knife, bowie-knife, switch-blade knife, ice pick, sling shot, sand club, metal knuckles, metal cake cutter, metal comb, razor, or any other dangerous or deadly weapons of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to jewelry, belts or other wearing apparel fashioned in such a manner so as to allow the use of the same as a weapon rather than as wearing apparel. The provisions hereof shall not apply to the transportation of such items to one's home when purchased for the use in such home and contained within the package in which the same was contained on purchase, nor shall the provisions hereof apply to hunters, fishermen, sportsmen, campers or workmen while such items are being transported for recreational or occupational purposes. 
(Ord. of 4-27-43, § 3; Ord. No. 71-253, § 1, 9-28-71) 
Sec. 14-66. - Exclusion from chapter. 
The preceding sections of this chapter are not applicable to pawnbrokers and pawnbrokers' sales stores, they being regulated by provisions of this Code specifically relating to them; but this chapter is applicable to all other persons, and the words "persons" or "person," as used herein, shall in addition to them, include their managers, agents, clerks and employees. 
(Ord. of 4-27-43, § 2) 
Sec. 14-67. - Toy pistols, cartridges, etc.; forbidden. 
It shall be unlawful, within the corporate limits or the police district of the city, to sell, use or possess any toy pistol, toy gun, or other instrumentality designed for blank metallic cartridges, or to sell, use or possess any kind of blank metallic cartridges adaptable to use with toy pistols, toy guns, or other such instrumentalities. 
(Ord. of 6-7-27, § 1) 
Sec. 14-68. - Firing guns, pistols in city prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to fire any gun or pistol within the city; provided, this section shall not apply to gun clubs, military companies upon such part of the city as may be set apart and designated for the use of such gun clubs or military company, or to law enforcement officers in the discharge of their duties. 
(b)  The provisions of this section of the Code of Ordinances of Columbus, Georgia shall not apply where written permission for the discharge of such firearm has been given to and is in the possession of the person discharging same by the owner of the property on which said firearm is discharged or when the owner is present and has granted oral permission to the individual discharging said firearm, and, in either event, where the firing is so controlled that no bullet, projectile, or any matter so discharged shall cross the property line of the person granting such permission; and provided, further, that no shotgun shall be fired within 500 feet, and no shotgun discharging a slug, and no other firearm of any kind shall be fired within 1,000 feet of the property line of any property on which a private residence or any other building occupied by a person or persons is located, other than a residence or other occupied building which is located on the property on which the firearm is discharged; and provided, further, that no shotgun discharging a slug and no rifle of any kind may be discharged on any property in Columbus, Georgia not in an A-1 zone; and provided, further, that the provisions of this section shall not apply where a shooting gallery is completely contained within a closed building. 
(Code 1914, § 794; Ord. No. 71-99, § 2, 4-27-71; Ord. No. 81-28, 3-24-81; Ord. No. 85-133, § 1, 12-3-85) 
Sec. 14-68.1. - Discharging air guns, crossbows, etc.; permission required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any air gun or air pistol, or any longbow, crossbow, or any other type of bow designed to discharge arrows, in any of the streets or sidewalks of Columbus, Georgia or in any of the lots thereof unless permission for the discharge of such devices has been given to the person discharging same by the owner of the property on which said devices are discharged, and unless the discharging of same is so controlled that no pellet, shot, arrow, or any matter so discharged shall cross the property line of the person granting such permission. 
(Ord. No. 62-124, §§ 1, 2, 11-26-62; Ord. No. 85-133, § 2, 12-3-85) 
Sec. 14-69. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any portion of this article shall, upon conviction in the recorder's court, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. A single act or omission contrary to the terms hereof shall constitute a punishable violation. 
(Ord. of 5-10-49, § 3) 
Secs. 14-70—14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 84-11, enacted Feb. 7, 1984, amended the title of Art. III to read as set forth above. Formerly Art. III was entitled "Purchase and Sale of Articles Commonly Stolen and Traded." Sections 2—4 of Ord. No. 84-11 amended several sections within the article in conformance with the title change. 
Cross reference— Dealers in secondhand jewelry, precious metals and gems, Ch. 10; junk and scrap metal dealers, § 14-41; pawnbrokers, Ch. 15. 

Sec. 14-81. - Secondhand dealers defined. 
Secondhand dealers covered by this article shall include for profit trade shops, swap shops, flea markets, and thrift shops, and any other person who buys or receives for the purpose of resale for profit used or new property which is still capable of being used for the purpose for which it was originally intended; but this article does not cover secondhand dealers, such as pawnbrokers and dealers in precious metals and gems, who are covered by other provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-101, § 1, 8-19-80; Ord. No. 84-11, § 2, 2-7-84; Ord. No. 90-92, 10-9-90) 
Note— See the editor's footnote at the beginning of this article. 
Sec. 14-82. - Registry; information required. 
Every dealer in the articles described herein shall keep a registry which shall contain the following information in connection with the purchase by such dealer of such article or articles: 
(1)  The name of the person or other entity from whom the article is purchased; 
(2)  The residence or place of business of such person or entity; 
(3)  Identification of such person or entity, including driver's license number or vehicle plate number of the seller; 
(4)  The name and address of the person or other entity from whom the article was acquired by the person selling the article to the dealer; 
(5)  A full description of each seller; and 
(6)  A serial and/or identifying number where available shall be secured from the seller. 
(Ord. No. 80-101, § 2, 8-19-80) 
Sec. 14-83. - Retention and availability of registry. 
(a)  The registry required by this article shall be retained by the dealer for a minimum of 90 days. 
(b)  Each dealer shall make the registry required herein available for inspection by any officer of the Columbus Police Department. 
(c)  In addition to the record-keeping requirements of this article, secondhand dealers will also be required to keep on their business premises, for a period of seven days, all items purchased or traded, and such items will not be altered in any manner and shall be open for inspection by law enforcement officers or the general public. 
(Ord. No. 80-101, § 3, 8-19-80; Ord. No. 84-11, § 3, 2-7-84) 
Note— See the editor's footnote at the beginning of this article. 
Sec. 14-84. - Duty of seller to furnish accurate information. 
Any seller of articles described herein shall give accurate, true and correct facts to the dealer, of all information required under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-101, § 4, 8-19-80) 
Sec. 14-85. - Violations. 
It shall be unlawful for secondhand dealers or their agents to purchase or trade secondhand items from any seller or trader without first obtaining the information required by this article and without keeping and signing the records and allowing inspection of the goods as required by this article; it shall be unlawful for sellers or traders to dispose of merchandise in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-101, § 5, 8-19-80; Ord. No. 84-11, § 4, 2-7-84) 
Note— See the editor's footnote at the beginning of this article. 
Secs. 14-86—14-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADULT-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 86-124, adopted Nov. 18, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code; hence codification of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as § 14-96, comprising a new Art. IV, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Public parks, § 4-41.1 et seq.; buildings, Ch. 8; licenses generally, § 19-11 et seq., zoning, Ch. 22; definitions of terms § 22-3. 

Sec. 14-96. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  Establishments or businesses which have as a major or predominant activity the sale of items defined under the term "adult bookstore" in the Columbus Zoning Ordinance or the Official Code of Georgia, and the showing of films defined under the term "adult movie house" in said ordinance and said Code shall not be located within a 600-foot radius of any property used for the following purposes or functions: 
(1)  Churches. 
(2)  Public or private schools and nursery schools. 
(3)  Parks and playgrounds. 
(4)  Teen centers. 
(5)  Libraries and museums. 
(6)  Buildings used for governmental purposes. 
(b)  Measurement of radius. The radius provided in this section shall be measured by following a straight line, without regard to intervening buildings, from the nearest point of the property parcel upon which the proposed use is to be located, to the nearest point of the parcel of property from which the proposed use is to be separated. 
(c)  Certificate to accompany license application. All license applications for such businesses shall include a certificate from a registered surveyor showing a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises, and the distance of the proposed premises from any prohibited location as determined under subsection (a). Such survey shall be coordinated and conducted by a registered surveyor contracted by the city, and the nonrefundable cost of such survey shall be paid by the applicant to the Columbus Consolidated Government when the license application is submitted. 
(Ord. No. 86-124, 11-18-86; Ord. No. 01-52, 6-19-01) 
Sec. 14-97. - Sexually explicit presentations harmful to minors. 
(a)  Definition. The term "harmful to minors" means that quality of any description or representation, in whatever form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sado-masochistic abuse, when it: 
(1)  Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of minors; 
(2)  Is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors; and 
(3)  Is utterly without redeeming social importance for minors. 
(b)  Admission to certain performances; selling tickets prohibited. It shall be unlawful to knowingly admit minors under the age of 18 years to performances conducted in the facilities of or on the property of the consolidated government in which live sexually explicit presentations of the following nature, which are harmful to minors, are rendered or to sell tickets to such minors for such performances: 
(1)  Nudity involving the showing of male or female genitals or buttocks or nipples of female breasts; 
(2)  Simulations of acts of sexual intercourse or masturbation or the showing of erections of the male penis, regardless of whether or not performers making such simulations and showings are clothed or unclothed; 
(3)  Pictures or models in conjunction with performances for the purpose of portraying sexual organs or sexual conduct prohibited in the foregoing paragraphs; 
(4)  Use of four-letter sexual words, particularly such use which is repetitious in nature or designed to sexually stimulate the audience; or 
(5)  Portrayals of sado-masochistic abuse involving torture or whipping or other assault of one person upon another, particularly where one or both or all parties are clad in undergarments or other thin attire, or masks or costumes, or where the victim is physically restrained in any manner. 
(c)  Exhibitions; objectionable language. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit himself or herself to an audience attended by minors under the age of 18 years in the manner forbidden in the foregoing section or to actively use before such audiences objects or pictures or language forbidden by the foregoing section, and it shall be unlawful for any person to direct or manage or promote a presentation forbidden by the foregoing section before such audiences. 
(Ord. No. 87-32, §§ 1—3, 3-17-87) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 87-32, §§ 1—3, adopted Mar. 17, 1987, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as § 14-97, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 14-98—14-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 90-28, adopted April 10, 1990, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ 1—9 of such ordinance as a new Art. V, §§ 14-201—14-209, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Excessive noise at public assemblies prohibited, § 17B-1. 

Sec. 14-201. - Purpose. 
It is the intent of the governing body of the consolidated government of Columbus to ensure its citizens an environment free from such excessive sound as may jeopardize their health, welfare and safety, or degrade the quality of life. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 1, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-202. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article: 
"A" band level means the total sound level of all noise as measured with a sound level meter using the "A" weighting network. The unit is the db(A). 
Ambient noise means the all-encompassing noise associated with a given environment, usually being a composite of sounds with many sources near and far. 
Band-pressure level of a sound for a specified frequency band means the sound-pressure level for the sound contained within the restricted band. 
Commercial district means the following: 
(1)  An area where offices, clinics and the facilities needed to serve them are located; 
(2)  An area with local shopping and service establishments; 
(3)  A tourist-oriented area where hotels, motels, and gasoline stations are located; 
(4)  A business strip along a main street containing offices, retail businesses, and commercial enterprises; 
(5)  Other commercial enterprises and activities which do not involve the manufacturing, processing or fabrication of any commodity. 
Commercial district shall include, but not be limited to, any parcel of land zoned commercial under the Zoning Ordinance of Columbus, Georgia. 
Commercial purpose means and includes the use, operation or maintenance of any sound-amplifying equipment for the purpose of conducting a business operation or function, or for the purpose of advertising any business, any goods, or any services, or for the purpose of attracting the attention of the public to, or advertising for or soliciting the patronage of customers to or for any performance, show, entertainment, exhibition or event, or for the purpose of demonstrating any such sound equipment. 
Construction activities means any and all activity incidental to the erection, demolition, assembling, altering, installing or equipping of buildings, structures, roads or appurtenances thereto, including land clearing, grading, excavating and filling. 
Consumer fireworks means any small fireworks as defined by O.C.G.A. § 25-10-(a)(1). 
Continuous noise means a steady, fluctuating, or impulsive noise which exists, essentially without interruption, for a period of ten minutes or more, with an accumulation of an hour or more over a period of eight hours. 
Cycle means the complete sequence of values of a periodic quantity which occurs during a period. 
Decibel (db) means a logarithmic and dimensionless unit of measure often used in describing the amplitude of sound. 
Device means any mechanism which is intended to produce or which actually produces sound when operated or handled. 
Dynamic braking device means a device used primarily on trucks for the conversion of the motor from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes. 
Emergency vehicle means a motor vehicle used in response to a public calamity or to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
Emergency work means work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger or potential danger. 
Fluctuating noise means the sound pressure level of a fluctuating noise which varies more than six db(A) during the period of observation when measured with the slow meter characteristic of a sound level meter. 
Frequency of a function periodic in time means the reciprocal of the primitive period. The unit is the cycle per unit time and shall be specified. 
Industrial district means an area in which enterprises and activities which involve the manufacturing, processing or fabrication of any commodity are located. Industrial district shall include but not be limited to, any parcel of land zoned as an industrial district, under the Zoning Ordinance of Columbus, Georgia. 
Microbar means a unit of pressure commonly used in acoustics and is equal to one dyne per square centimeter. 
Motor vehicle means any two or more wheeled vehicle or machine, propelled or drawn by mechanical power and used on the public roads and highways in the transportation of passengers or property, which is required to be licensed but does not include vehicles operated exclusively on rails. 
Noncommercial purpose means the use, operation or maintenance of any sound equipment for other than a commercial purpose. Noncommercial purpose shall mean and include, but shall not be limited to, philanthropic, political, patriotic and charitable purposes. 
Period, of a periodic quantity, means the smallest increment of time for which the function repeats itself. 
Periodic quantity means oscillating quantity, the values of which recur for equal increments of time. 
Plainly audible sound means any sound from which the information content of that sound is unambiguously transferred to the listener, such as but not limited to, understandable spoken speech, comprehension of whether a voice is raised or normal, or comprehension of musical rhythm. 
Residential district means an area of single-or multiple-family dwellings and shall include areas where multiple-unit dwellings, high-rise apartments and high-density residential districts are located. Residential district also includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, nursing homes, homes for the aged, schools, courts and similar institutional facilities. 
Sound analyzer means a device for measuring the band pressure level or pressure spectrum level of a sound as a function of frequency. 
Sound-amplifying equipment means any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music, or any other sound. Sound-amplifying equipment shall not include standard automobile radios when used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which the automobile radio is installed. Sound-amplifying equipment, as used in this article, shall not include warning devices or authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on any vehicle used only for traffic safety purposes.
