Sound-level meter means an instrument including a microphone, an amplifier, an output meter, and frequency weighting networks for the measurement of noise and sound levels in a specified manner. 
Sound-pressure level, in decibels of a sound means 20 times the logarithm to the base ten of the ratio of the pressure of this sound to the reference pressure, which reference pressure shall be explicitly stated. 
Sound truck means any motor vehicle, or any other vehicle regardless of motive power, whether in motion or stationary, having mounted thereon, or attached thereto, any sound-amplifying equipment. 
Spectrum, of a function of time, means a description of its resolution into components, each of a different frequency. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 2, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-203. - Decibel measurement criteria. 
Any decibel measurement made pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be based on a reference sound pressure of 0.0002 microbars as measured in any octave band with center frequency, in cycles per second, as follows: 63, 125, 250, 500, 1,000, 2,000, 4,000 and 8,000 or as measured with a sound level meter using the "A" weighting. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 3, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-204. - Special noise sources. 
(a)  Radio, television sets, and similar devices: 
(1)  Use restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or permit to be played any radio receiving set, musical instrument, television, phonograph, drum or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of neighboring residents or any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing in the area. 
(2)  Prima facie violation. The operation of any such set, instrument, television, phonograph, machine or device at any time in such a manner as to create a plainly audible sound at either the property line in a residential district or 50 feet from any such device located on public rights-of-way or public property or 25 feet from the property line of property located within a commercial district on which such device is operated or in such a manner to create any noise exceeding the ambient noise level at the property line of any property (or, if a condominium or apartment house, within any adjoining apartment) by more than five decibels shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this subsection. 
(b)  Hawkers and peddlers. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to sell anything by outcry within any area of the city zoned for residential uses. The provisions of this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the selling by outcry of merchandise, food and beverages at licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses, and other similar licensed public entertainment events. 
(c)  Animals. No person shall keep or maintain or permit the keeping of, on any premises owned, occupied or controlled by such person, any animal or bird otherwise permitted to be kept, which by frequent or habitual howling, barking, meowing, squawking, or other noise unreasonably disturbs the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or causes discomfort or annoyance to any person. 
(d)  Machinery, equipment, pumps and fans. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any machinery, equipment, pump, fan, or similar mechanical device in any manner so as to create any noise which would cause the noise level at the property line of any property to exceed the ambient noise level by more than five decibels based on a reference sound pressure of 0.0002 microbars as measured in any octave band center frequency, in cycles per second, as follows: 63, 125, 250, 500, 1,000, 2,000, 4,000, and 8,000, and for the combined frequency bands, "A" band. The provisions of this paragraph shall not apply to machinery and equipment being used for on-site construction. 
(e)  Vehicle repairs. It shall be unlawful for any person within any residential area of the city to repair, rebuild or test any motor vehicle (between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day) in such a manner that a reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing in that area is caused discomfort or annoyance. 
(f)  Train horns and whistles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or sound, or cause to be operated or sounded between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day, a train horn or train whistle which creates a noise in excess of 89 db(A) at any place or point 300 feet or more distant from the source of such sound, unless such sound is required as a warning device under state or federal law. 
(g)  Mufflers. No person shall discharge into the open air the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, air compressor equipment, motorboat, motor vehicle, or other power device, which is not equipped with an adequate muffler in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any unnecessary noise, and no such muffler or exhaust system shall be modified or used with a cutoff, bypass, or similar device. 
(h)  Trucks. No person shall load any garbage, trash on compactor truck, or any other truck, whereby the loading, unloading or handling of boxes, crates, equipment or other objects is conducted within a residential district or within 300 feet of any hotel or motel between the hours of 10:00 pm. and 7:00 a.m. 
(i)  Exhausts. The maximum permissible sound pressure levels of any continuous source of sound shall be as herein established for the time period and district listed in Table A of this section. This includes, but is not limited to, sound from such activities as production, processing, cleaning, servicing, testing, operating, or repairing either vehicles, materials, goods, products or devices. Sound pressure levels in excess of those established for the zoned districts of the city, in times herewith listed, shall constitute prima facie evidence that such sound is an unnecessary noise and a violation of this subsection. Sound pressure levels shall be measured at the approximate location of the property line or the boundary of the public right-of-way, at a height of at least four feet above the immediate surrounding surface, on a sound level meter of standard design and operated on the "A" weighting network. 
TABLE A 

 
The sound pressure level limits, and provision hereof, applicable to commercial districts shall also apply to any parcel of land zoned as an agricultural district under the Zoning Ordinance of Columbus, Georgia. 
The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to motor vehicles operating on public rights-of-way; and bell or chime or any device for the production or reproduction of the sound of bells or chimes from any church, clock or school; the loading of any trucks; domestic power equipment and commercial power equipment. 
(j)  Construction. Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall engage in, cause or permit any person to be engaged in construction activities in any residential or commercial district between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the following day. 
Construction activities directly connected with the abatement of an emergency are excluded from the provisions of this subsection. 
(k)  Small power equipment. No person shall operate or permit to be operated on private property or on the public right-of-way within any residential or commercial district(s) any power equipment rated five horsepower or less and used for home and building repair or grounds maintenance between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day. Such power equipment shall include, but not be limited to, lawn mowers, garden tools, snow removal equipment, electric or chain saws or any other power equipment used for home or building repair or grounds maintenance. Noise sound pressure levels shall be measured at a distance of 25 feet from the noise source. 
(l)  Power tools. No person shall operate on any property within a residential or commercial district or on any public right-of-way within a residential or commercial district, any power equipment rated more than five horsepower used for constructions, including but not limited to, chain saws, pavement breakers, log chippers, riding tractors, or powered hand tools, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the next day. 
(m)  Sound amplifiers. The commercial and noncommercial use of sound amplifying equipment shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The sound amplifying equipment shall be operated only between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of each day unless an extension of such hours is authorized by the chief of police after consideration of the standards set forth in subsection (p). 
(2)  The maximum sound emanating from sound-amplifying equipment shall not exceed the sound pressure levels established in subsection (i) as measured at least 25 feet from the noise source. 
(3)  In any event, the intensity of sound shall be so controlled that it will not be unreasonably loud, raucous, annoying, disturbing, or a nuisance to any person or persons. 
(4)  The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to any bell or chime or any device for the production or reproduction of the sound of bells or chimes from any church, clock or school. 
(n)  Warning signals. No person shall sound any horn or signaling device on any truck, automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle on any street or highway within the city, except as a danger warning, and then only for a reasonable period of time. 
(o)  Emergency work. Noise caused in the performance of emergency work for the immediate safety, health or welfare of the citizens located in the city, or to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(p)  Consumer fire works. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership to use or ignite or cause to be ignited any consumer fireworks, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1(a)(1): between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Provided; however, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 25-10-2(b)(3)(B)(ii) and (iii), it shall be lawful for any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership to use or ignite or cause to be ignited any consumer fireworks on January 1, the last Saturday and Sunday in May, July 3, July 4 and December 31 of each year after the time of 10:00 pm and up to and including the time of 11:59 pm; and On January 1 of each year beginning at the time of 12:00 midnight and up to and including the ending time of 1:00 a.m. The intent of this paragraph is to impose the same restrictions as to time on consumer fireworks as are applied to other special noise sources except where state law requires additional leniency. 
(q)  Additional regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing in the area. 
The standards which shall be considered in determining whether a violation of the provisions of this subsection exists shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The volume of the noise; 
(2)  The intensity of the noise; 
(3)  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual; 
(4)  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural; 
(5)  The volume and intensity of the background noise, if any; 
(6)  The proximity of the noise to residential sleeping facilities; 
(7)  The nature and zoning of the area within the noise emanates; 
(8)  The density of the inhabitation of the area within which the noise emanates; 
(9)  The time of the day or night the noise occurs; 
(10)  The duration of the noise; 
(11)  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent or constant; 
(12)  Whether the noise is produced by a commercial or noncommercial activity. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 4, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 96-17, §§ 1, 2, 3-5-96; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-205. - Amplified sound. 
(a)  Registration required. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than personnel of law enforcement or governmental agencies, to install, use, or operate within the city a loudspeaker or sound-amplifying equipment in a fixed or movable position or mounted upon any sound truck for the purposes of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures, or transmitting music to any persons or assemblages of persons in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, park, or public property without first filing a registration statement and obtaining approval thereof as set forth in this section. 
(b)  Registration requirements and duties: 
(1)  Registration statements—Filing. Every user of sound-amplifying equipment shall file a registration statement with the chief of police five days prior to the date on which the sound-amplifying equipment is intended to be used, which statement shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of both the owner and user of the sound amplifying equipment; 
b.  The maximum sound-producing power of the sound-amplifying equipment which shall include the wattage to be used, the volume in decibels of sound which will be produced, and the approximate distance for which sound will be audible from the sound-amplifying equipment; 
c.  The license and motor number if a sound truck is to be used; 
d.  A general description of the sound-amplifying equipment which is to be used; and 
e.  Whether the sound-amplifying equipment will be used for commercial or noncommercial purposes. 
(2)  Registration statements—Approval. The chief of police shall return to the applicant an approved certified copy of the registration statement unless he finds that: 
a.  The conditions of the motor vehicle movement are such that use of the equipment would constitute a detriment to traffic safety; or 
b.  The conditions of pedestrian movement are such that use of the equipment would constitute a detriment to traffic safety; or 
c.  The registration statement reveals that the applicant would not be able to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  Registration statements—Disapproval. In the event the registration statement is disapproved, the chief of police shall endorse upon the statement his reasons for disapproval and return it forthwith to the applicant, who may appeal such disapproval to the Columbus Council. 
(c)  Fees. Prior to the issuance of the registration statement, a fee in the amount of $25.00 per day, or any portion thereof, shall be paid to the city, if the loudspeaker or sound-amplifying equipment is to be used for commercial purposes. No fee shall be required for the operation of a loudspeaker or sound-amplifying equipment for noncommercial purposes. 
(d)  Regulations. The commercial and noncommercial use of sound-amplifying equipment shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The only sounds permitted shall be either music or human speech, or both. 
(2)  The operation of sound-amplifying equipment shall only occur between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. each day except on Sundays and legal holidays. No operation of sound-amplifying equipment for commercial purposes shall be permitted on Sundays or legal holidays. The operation of sound-amplifying equipment for noncommercial purposes on Sundays and legal holidays shall only occur between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(3)  No sound emanating from sound-amplifying equipment shall exceed 15 db(A) above the ambient as measured at any property line. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to operate any sound-amplifying equipment within 200 feet of churches, schools, hospitals or city buildings. 
(5)  In any event, the volume of sound shall be so controlled that it will not be unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or a nuisance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness within the area of audibility. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 5, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-206. - Periodic review. 
The provisions of this article shall be reviewed from time to time by the Columbus Health Department, and the health department shall make recommendations at least once each year to whether the regulations set out in this article shall be amended or expanded. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 6, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-207. - Exceptions. 
The prohibitions of this article shall not apply to air traffic at the Columbus Metropolitan Airport, parades, chimes, bells, cultural events, athletic games, or recreational activities or other functions authorized or licensed by the consolidated government or other governmental agency. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 7, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-208. - Existing businesses. 
Businesses are allowed one year from April 10, 1990, to come into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 8, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Sec. 14-209. - Violations; penalties. 
Any violations of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 9, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 97-58, 6-10-97; Ord. No. 18-38, § 1, 7-31-18) 
Secs. 14-210—14-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 93-79, adopted Sept. 14, 1993, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—11 as Ch. 14, Art. VI, §§ 14-221—14-231, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 14-221. - Adult entertainment establishments prohibited where designated. 
After the effective date of this article it shall be unlawful to locate any adult entertainment establishment on sites prohibited by this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 1, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 1, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-222. - Establishments existing at the time of enactment of this article. 
It shall be unlawful for adult entertainment establishments either existing at the time of the enactment of this article or established thereafter to be operated in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 2, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 2, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-223. - "Adult entertainment establishment" defined. 
Adult entertainment establishments are defined as businesses in which, as the major activity, customers congregate primarily for the purpose of viewing or associating with employees who display anatomical areas designed to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification: human genitals, the immediate pubic region, or pubic hair; buttocks to the extent of exposing the immediate anal area; female breasts to points below the nipples; male genitals in a state of erection, even if covered with opaque clothing; all of the above anatomical areas when covered only by transparent or diaphanous clothing. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 3, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 3, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-224. - Identification when applying for license. 
All businesses engaging in activities defined by the term "adult entertainment establishment" shall so identify themselves when applying for licenses or permits or certificates from any division or department of the consolidated government, and no such license or permit or certificate shall be issued unless the premises and the persons owning or operating the businesses comply with the criteria in this article; however, any such business located on a site that was not prohibited prior to the enactment of this article may renew but not transfer its license to operate. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 4, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 4, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-225. - Permits. 
In addition to all other requirements for doing business in Columbus, Georgia, adult entertainment establishments and all employees thereof shall be required to apply for and obtain a permit from the chief of police certifying compliance with this article. A non-refundable fee in the amount of $6.00 shall be charged for the preparation of each permit. It shall be the responsibility of the employer to see that the employees are carrying with them an identification permit at all times they are working. Said identification permit will expire each year on the birth date of the applicant and must be renewed at such time, and said permit must at all times be in the possession of such person affected hereunder for him or her to be eligible to engage in such business. In making decisions to grant or deny permits, the chief of police shall only consider whether an applicant has strictly complied with this article and its requirements. Said permits shall be either issued or denied within thirty (30) days of application. If an applicant is dissatisfied with the decision of the chief of police, the applicant may appeal to the Superior Court of Muscogee County within thirty (30) days of the decision. If no decision is rendered by the chief of police within thirty (30) days of filing a completed application for a permit, said permit shall be deemed approved. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 5, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 5, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 00-28, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 02-24, § 1, 3-19-02) 
Sec. 14-226. - Location. 
No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 600 feet of the property line of any church, school, community teen center, library, nursery school, day care center, playground, residential zone, or condominiums and multiple-family dwellings and townhouses located in A-O zones. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 6, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 6, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-227. - Persons convicted of felony or misdemeanor. 
No person shall own, manage, operate in any manner or be employed in any capacity by an adult entertainment establishment who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any federal or state felony within five years of applying for the permit from the chief of police necessary to do business or to be employed, nor shall any such person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any federal or state misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within two years of such application be issued such a permit. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 7, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 7, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-228. - Private modeling sessions prohibited. 
No adult entertainment establishment shall allow and no employee thereof shall engage in private modeling sessions or other activities involving sexual displays in which one employee is placed in a one-on-one situation with one customer, and a regular show area with open seating shall be required for such sessions or displays; neither shall any adult entertainment establishment or any employee thereof allow personal physical contact or close mingling between customers and employees. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 8, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 8, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-229. - Admitting minors prohibited. 
All adult entertainment establishments are prohibited during regular business hours from admitting minors as defined by O.C.G.A. § 39-1-1. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 9, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 9, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-230. - License revocation. 
The chief of police is empowered to recommend the revocation of the license of any adult entertainment establishment in which the owner is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to any provisions of this article or any federal or state felony or any federal or state misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and the chief of police is empowered to recommend the revocation of the license of any adult entertainment establishment in which a manager or any employee (or employees) in two or more separate incidents on separate occasions is convicted of or enters pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any such violation. 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 10, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 10, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 14-231. - Procedures for revocation. 
The procedures for revocation shall be the same as the procedure required by Columbus Code section 3-11(b). 
(Ord. No. 93-79, § 11, 9-14-93; Ord. No. 96-21, § 11, 3-19-96) 
Secs. 14-233—14-249. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ESCORT SERVICES 

Sec. 14-250. - Annual regulatory fee. 
Escort services permitted under O.C.G.A § 48-13-9 shall pay an annual regulatory fee of $5,000.00 to the consolidated government of Columbus, Georgia. All escort service businesses shall pay said annual regulatory fee plus an occupation tax as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Sec. 14-251. - Annual identification card. 
Any person applying for an escort service business license shall apply for the same in the occupation tax section of the revenue division of the consolidated government. Upon payment of the regulatory fee pursuant to section 14-250 of this Code, all owners, licensees and employees of the business shall submit to a background check and obtain an annual identification card from the chief of police certifying compliance with this article. It shall be the responsibility of the employer to see that the employees are carrying with them an identification card at all times they are working. Said identification card will expire each year on the birth date of the applicant and must be renewed at such time, and said card must at all times be in the possession of such person affected hereunder for him or her to be eligible to engage in such business. In making decisions to grant or deny identification cards, the chief of police shall only consider whether an applicant has strictly complied with this article and its requirements. Said cards shall be either issued or denied within 30 days of application. If an applicant is dissatisfied with the decision of the chief of police, the applicant may appeal to the Superior Court of Muscogee County within 30 days of the decision. If no decision is rendered by the chief of police within 30 days of filing a completed application for an identification card, said card shall be deemed approved. 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Sec. 14-252. - Prohibited locations. 
No escort service business authorized under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 shall be located within 600 feet of the property line of any church, school, community teen center, library, nursery school, day care center, playground, residential zone, or condominiums and multiple-family dwellings and townhouses located in A-O zones. No home occupation license shall be granted for an escort service business. All applications for new escort service business licenses shall include a certificate from a registered surveyor showing a scale drawing of the location of the proposed business and the distance of the proposed business from any prohibited locations described in this code section. Such survey shall be coordinated and conducted by a registered surveyor contracted by the city, and the nonrefundable cost of such survey shall be paid by the applicant to the Columbus Consolidated Government when the application is submitted, in addition to the regulatory fee. 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Sec. 14-253. - Persons convicted of felony or misdemeanor. 
No person shall own, manage, operate in any manner or be employed in any capacity by an escort service business who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any federal or state felony within ten years of applying for the permit from the chief of police necessary to do business or to be employed, nor shall any such person who has been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any federal or state misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or loitering for purposes of prostitution or sodomy within five years of such application be issued such a permit. 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Sec. 14-254. - Other prohibitions. 
All escort service businesses are prohibited at all times from employing minors as defined by O.C.G.A. § 39-1-1. It shall be unlawful for an escort service business to allow or for any employee thereof to engage in private modeling sessions or other activities involving sexual conduct or sexually explicit nudity as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-102 in which one employee is placed in a one-on-one situation with one customer. 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Sec. 14-255. - License revocation. 
The chief of police is empowered to recommend the revocation of the license of any escort service business in which the owner is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to any provisions of this article or any federal or state felony or any federal or state misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or loitering for purposes of prostitution or sodomy. The chief of police is empowered to recommend the revocation of the license of any escort service business in which a manager or any employee (or employees) is convicted on two or more separate occasions within any 48-month period of or enters pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any such violation. The procedures for revocation shall be the same as the procedure required by Columbus Code subsection 3-11(b). 
(Ord. No. 06-25, § 1, 4-18-06) 
Chapter 15 - PAWNBROKERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 81-21, enacted March 5, 1981, repealed former Ch. 15, §§ 15-1—15-9, and enacted, in lieu thereof, a new Ch. 15 as herein set forth. Former Ch. 15 pertained to pawnbrokers and dealers in precious metals and gems and derived from Ord. No. 80-149, § 1, adopted Dec. 23, 1980, as amended by Ord. No. 81-10, § 1, enacted Feb. 3, 1981. 
Cross reference— Dealers in secondhand jewelry, precious metals, etc., Ch. 10; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 16; license fees for pawnbrokers, § 19-47(6340). 

Sec. 15-1. - Applicability. 
This chapter shall apply to all pawnbrokers in Columbus, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 15-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Employee means: 
(1)  Any owner or pawn broker who, in the performance of his or her duties or the management of the business affairs of a pawnshop, comes into contact with members of the public; or 
(2)  Any person working for an owner or pawnbroker; or 
(3)  Any person who is employed on a part-time basis, either with or without remuneration, by a pawnshop. 
Owner. Any person or partner or stockholder owning 25 percent or more of a business. 
Pawn or pledge means a bailment of personal property as security for any debt or engagement, redeemable upon certain terms and with the power of sale on default. 
Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81; Ord. No. 05-4, § 1, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 15-3. - Regulatory fee. 
All businesses involving pawnbrokers shall pay an annual regulatory fee of $150.00, plus an occupation tax as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 05-4, § 2, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 15-4. - Revocation of licenses. 
(a)  Licenses issued under this chapter may be revoked upon a conviction of the licensee or an employee of the licensee or plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or an employee of the licensee in the recorder's court or any other court of a violation of any of this chapter's provisions or upon a conviction of the licensee or an employee of the licensee or plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or an employee of the licensee in any state of any felony involving any offense or any misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses. 
(b)  The following procedures shall be followed in the revocation of licenses under this chapter: 
(1)  Notice shall be given to the holder of a license at least two weeks in advance that the Council of Columbus, Georgia, will hear a recommendation that the license be revoked, and this notice shall include the specific grounds on which this recommendation to council will be made. 
(2)  The clerk of council shall notify the license holder, the director of finance, and the chief of police, or the director of public safety, as to the time that a recommendation for revocation will be heard. 
(3)  The Council of Columbus, Georgia, shall hear a recommendation for revocation at one of its regular meetings, at which time the holder of a license and any other interested parties will be heard. 
(4)  No license shall be revoked until a majority of the council so decides at the time of or subsequent to the hearing on the recommendation for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 15-5. - Character requirements. 
No license shall be issued to or renewed for any person who conducts a business in which the owner or manager or any employee has, within five years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to any felony involving any offense or any misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses, in any state; and all licensees shall submit the identity of all owners and managers and employees to the Columbus Police Department and to the revenue collection division on a continuing basis as changes occur for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character requirements be fulfilled. No license shall be issued or renewed if it is determined that a person falsified, concealed, or misrepresented any material fact by any device, trick, or scheme while making application for the initial business license or any application for renewal. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81; Ord. No. 05-4, § 3, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 15-6. - Location of businesses. 
All businesses regulated by this chapter shall be conducted at an identifiable street address which shall be provided on a license or renewal application which itself shall be turned over to the Columbus Police Department, and no licensee shall change the address for any business without giving advance notice to both the revenue collection division and the Columbus Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 15-7. - Requirements upon receiving in pawn or purchasing items. 
All businesses regulated by this chapter shall fulfill the following requirements when receiving in pawn or purchasing: 
(a)  Require the pawner or seller to positively identify himself by driver's license, military I. D. card, alcohol beverage card, Social Security number, or any other means of identification that contains information re: Birthdate, sex, race, address, telephone number; and by any other relevant physical descriptive information, all of which will be contained on a form prescribed and provided to the business by the Columbus Police Department. 
(b)  Record on the same form which describes the pawner or seller a complete description of the merchandise pawned or purchased, including kind, style, material, color, design, and all identifying names, marks and numbers, and any distinguishing marks such as initials or serial numbers, as well as the time it was obtained by the pawner or purchaser and from whom it was obtained. 
(c)  For a period of seven days from the date of pawning or purchasing, post in a clearly visible or accessible place on the premises designated in the license for doing business the forms containing the above information, and hold on these premises in a place readily available for inspection by both law enforcement officials and the general public, all of these designated items in the same condition as they existed when first pawned or purchased. 
(d)  Require the pawner or seller to sign the police department form on a signature line which shall be preceded by the sentence "I do solemnly swear or affirm that the information provided by me on this form is true and correct. Adjacent to the pawner's or seller's signature there shall be affixed the right thumbprint of the pawner or seller, and the pawnbroker shall use ink and pad approved by the Columbus Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81; Ord. No. 86-127, 12-9-86) 
Sec. 15-8. - Daily reports. 
Every pawnbroker shall make a daily report, in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police, of all pawnshop transactions that occurred during 24 hours ending at 9:00 p.m. on the date of the report. 
(1)  Effective June 1, 2005, such daily reports shall be computer generated in a software format that is compatible with software utilized by the Columbus Police Department, or in other such form as may be permitted by the chief of police. 
(2)  Daily reports shall list all property pledged, traded, pawned, exchanged, or sold, the pawn transaction number for each transaction, and a description of the property including, to the extent possible, the manufacturer, model, serial number, style, material, kind, color, design, number of stones if jewelry, and any other identifying names, marks, and numbers. The daily report shall also list the name, address, race, sex, height, weight, date of birth, and social security number or the driver's license number of the person pledging, trading, pawning, exchanging, or selling the property, along with the date and time of the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 05-4, § 4, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 15-9. - Receiving in pawn or buying from minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any business regulated by this chapter to receive in pawn, trade, or to buy from minors, goods of any character or description. A minor, for the purpose of this chapter, is an individual 17 years of age or under. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Sec. 15-10. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 81-21, § 1, 3-5-81) 
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— For provisions relevant to peddling of agricultural products and implements, see Ga. Code, § 84-2010; for other provisions relevant to peddlers, see Title 84, Ch. 20. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Solicitations for charity—Permit required; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, directly or indirectly, to solicit property or financial assistance of any kind, to sell or offer to sell any article, tag, service emblem, publication, ticket, advertisement, subscription or anything of value, on the plea or the representation that such sale or solicitation or the proceeds thereof is for a charitable, educational, religious, patriotic or philanthropic purpose, on the streets, in any office or business building, by house-to-house canvass, or in any other public or private place, or by telephone, mail or personal solicitation or in any other way in the city unless such person shall have first obtained from the chief of police a permit to do so; provided, the provisions of this section shall not apply to persons where such solicitation or sales are made by the members of an organization to other members thereof without remuneration to the solicitor, or where such solicitation or sales occur upon property owned or leased by such persons; provided, however, that the permit required by this Code section shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance and shall be renewable on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 5-12-42, § 1; Ord. No. 96-61, 7-9-96) 
Sec. 16-2. - Same—Application; information. 
Such person desiring to do any of the acts detailed in the preceding section hereof shall first make a written application for a permit to do so to the chief of police. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Name of person and organization applying for a permit to solicit and the address of its headquarters together with any evidence of tax exempt status as defined by O.C.G.A. Section 48-7-25 or Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(b)  The name and address of the person who will be in direct charge of conducting this solicitation. 
(c)  The purpose for which any receipts derived from such solicitation are to be used. 
(Ord. of 5-12-42, § 2; Ord. No. 96-70, 7-30-96) 
Sec. 16-3. - Same—Investigation; denial of permit; waiver of provisions. 
Upon the filing of such application, the chief of police shall immediately make an investigation to determine the truth or falsity of the recitals in the application, and the amount of the net proceeds which it is contemplated will be received by the organization for which such soliciting or sales are performed. In the event the chief of police determines that the organization in whose name such soliciting or sales are done will not receive at least 75 percent of the net proceeds derived from such solicitation or sales, he shall refuse to issue a permit for such soliciting or sales; and in the event he determines that any of the material statements of facts in such application are false, he shall likewise refuse to issue a permit. Where any person and the organization which he represents are known by the chief of police to come within the provisions above recited, the chief of police may waive the filing of a written application, and issue the permit provided by this section. 
(Ord. of 5-12-42, § 3) 
Sec. 16-4. - Same—Appeal, hearing, findings. 
Upon refusal of the chief of police to grant a permit, he shall notify the applicant, in writing, and within ten days thereof the applicant may appeal to the commission. If the commission, after a hearing, determines that the applicant is entitled to a permit, the commission shall, by resolution, direct the issuance of such permit by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 5-12-42, § 4) 
Sec. 16-5. - Farm products—Definition. 
The term farm products as used herein shall include vegetables, fruits, melons, chickens, eggs, dairy products, and all other products of farms or gardens. 
(Ord. of 7-13-48, § 1) 
Sec. 16-6. - Same—Delivery in street prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to peddle or sell farm products in the city where delivery of such products is made in the streets of the city; but it is not the intention hereof to prohibit the peddling or selling of such products where delivery is made directly to stores or residences. 
(Ord. of 7-13-48, § 2) 
Sec. 16-7. - Same—Time limitation on stopping vehicle. 
While engaged in travelling from residence to residence or from store to store and peddling or selling farm products to consumers, no vehicles shall stop in the same spot in the streets of the city for a longer period than 30 minutes. 
(Ord. of 7-13-48, § 3) 
Sec. 16-8. - Same—Near like businesses prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to peddle farm products to consumers in the streets of the city for any period of time while within 50 feet of a licensed store which keeps on hand or sells farm products. 
(Ord. of 7-13-48, § 4) 
Sec. 16-9. - Flowers or shrubbery—License or permit required for peddling. 
It shall be unlawful to peddle or offer for sale from house to house or place to place in the city or its police district any cut flowers, flower plants or shrubbery unless the person so peddling or offering the same for sale has with him at the time either a regular business license issued by the city or a written permit signed by the chief of police of the city. 
(Ord. of 3-28-33, § 1) 
Sec. 16-10. - Same—Persons excepted; places designated. 
The preceding section is not intended to prohibit the sale of wild flowers, evergreens or other plants or flowers by country people not regularly engaged in the flower business, where such sales are made at places in the city designated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 3-28-33, § 2) 
Sec. 16-11. - Fish—Door to door peddling prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or his agents, to peddle or offer for sale upon the streets or in other public places, or from house to house or store to store, in the city or its police district, from any truck, automobile, wagon, or other vehicle, or from a basket or other container, or otherwise, any fresh fish, oysters, shrimp, crab, lobster or similar fresh fish or seafoods. 
(Ord. of 3-29-32, § 1) 
Sec. 16-12. - Same—Exceptions. 
The provisions of the preceding section shall not apply to: 
(a)  The delivery of such fish or foods upon orders previously taken, where each such order is delivered in a separate package or container in which it is wrapped at the regularly located place of business of the seller. 
(b)  The peddling of strings of fresh fish caught within 25 miles of the city, where such fish are peddled within four hours after being caught. 
(Ord. of 3-29-32, § 2) 
Sec. 16-13. - Meat, peddling prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, by himself or agent, to peddle, sell, offer for sale, or to have in possession for the purpose of peddling, selling or offering for sale, any meat or meat products upon the streets or from house to house within the city or the police district thereof; provided, this section is not intended to interfere with the delivery of meat or meat products sold at or ordered from regular licensed butcher shops. 
(Ord. of 3-21-27, § 1) 
State Law reference— For provisions relevant to the inspection of meat products, see Ga. Code, §§ 42-401, 42-402, 42-406; as to sanitary regulations in the production of meat products, see §§ 42-401, 42-402. 
Secs. 16-14—16-30. - Reserved. 
Chapter 16B - PERSONNEL REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-213, adopted Aug. 17, 1971, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as Ch. 16B was at the discretion of the editors. The ordinance is set out as enacted; however, the word "chapter" was changed to "article" to preserve Code format, and the section numbers were prefixed by the chapter number of this Code and the chapter number in the ordinance, to facilitate reference and use. 
Charter reference— Organization of consolidated government, and general provisions, §§ 4-100—4-103; department of administration, § 4-400; personnel review board, § 4-610; pensions and personnel regulations, §§ 8-300—8-305; protection of existing employees, § 9-106. 

ARTICLE I. - OBJECTIVES AND SCOPE 

Sec. 16B-1-1. - Authority. 
Section 8-303 of the Charter provides that the department of administration shall prepare personnel regulations for the consideration of the city manager. When approved, the city manager shall submit the regulations to council for adoption in the form of an ordinance. The regulations may be amended in the same manner. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 1, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-1-2. - Purposes. 
The personnel regulations are adopted to provide for the recruitment and development of the best available employee for each position in the merit system of the consolidated government, Columbus, Georgia, at all times. They provide for establishing orderly procedures for personnel administration in such a way to ensure: 
(a)  That employment in the merit system of the government shall be made attractive as a career. 
(b)  That all appointments and promotions to positions in the merit system shall be on the sole basis of merit and fitness, which, as far as is practicable, shall be ascertained by means of competitive examinations, and that this government shall be an equal employment opportunity employer, and that applicants and employees shall not be discriminated against because of race, color, creed, sex, political affiliations, age, physical disability, national origin, or any other nonmerit factor. Exceptions may be made where a specific age, sex or physical requirement constitutes a bona fide occupational qualification necessary to proper and efficient administration. 
(c)  That position classification and pay plans shall be adopted which shall conform with the principle of equal pay for equal work. 
(d)  That a performance rating system shall be provided where economy and effectiveness in personal services may be promoted in the mutual benefit of the employees, government officials, taxpayers and all the people of the city. 
(e)  That each employee in the merit system shall be encouraged to render his best service to the government. 
(f)  To facilitate maximum utilization of manpower and public service, cooperation will be extended in the following areas where agreements can be ascertained: 
(1)  Interjurisdictional recruiting, examining, certifying, training and other personnel actions. 
(2)  Adding to registers of eligible applicants with eligibility on comparable examinations in other jurisdictions. 
(3)  Appointing employees on the basis of their permanent merit status in another jurisdiction, with maximum protection of their retirement and other benefits. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 2, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 75-20, §§ 1, 2, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-1-3. - Positions covered—Generally. 
These regulations shall apply to all positions specified in the Charter, section 8-302, Merit System. 
All positions in the service of the government shall be in the merit system except the following: 
(a)  Officers elected by the people and persons appointed to fill vacancies in elective offices; 
(b)  The members of boards, commissions and authorities; 
(c)  The city manager, city attorney, director of public safety, recorders and recorders pro tem, clerk of council, and heads and directors of departments; 
(d)  Persons temporarily employed in a professional or scientific capacity or to conduct a special inquiry investigation, examination or installation; 
(e)  Temporary or part-time employees; and 
(f)  Such other positions as may be excepted by ordinance of the council. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 3, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-1-3.1. - Same—Employees of elected county officers, commissions, boards, etc.. 
Elected county officers and commissions, boards, or other bodies in the consolidated government may, consistent with the terms of O.C.G.A. § 36-1-21 (1986 Ga. L. 764), place their employees within the merit system and under the jurisdiction of the personnel review board by making written application to the clerk of council, and such coverage of such employees shall be effective from the date of the filing of the application without any further action by the Columbus Council. 
(Ord. No. 86-73, 7-8-86) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 86-73, adopted July 8, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of the substantive provisions of the ordinance as § 16B-1-3.1 was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 16B-1-3.2. - Hiring or rehiring of felons; exceptions; executive committee review. 
In all general government departments of the consolidated government, it shall be the policy that otherwise qualified individuals who have been convicted of or pled guilty or nolo contendere to felony offenses in any court of Georgia or other state or in any United States District Court, including parole or other forms of court ordered supervision for felony crimes will not be excluded from consideration for hiring where doing so does not unduly put the government, its employees or the citizens at risk. There shall be an executive committee, composed of the mayor, the mayor pro-tem, the city manager, the director of human resources, and a representative of the law enforcement to be appointed by the mayor which is charged with the responsibility of reviewing the cases where an applicant who has a criminal record as described above has been recommended by a hiring department and the department of human resources for a specific position. The executive committee shall review and approve such applicants by a majority vote of the total membership of five and only after giving due consideration to the needs of the government and the public interest involved as well as the likelihood that such an exception will be conducive to the rehabilitation efforts of the prospective employee involved. In evaluating a candidate, the executive committee shall take into consideration the severity of the crime and any recommendations that may be offered by prison or parole or probation officers, opinions of past job performance with the consolidated government or other employers, and the nature or sensitivity of the position to be filled with emphasis on the question of whether or not the previous crime is predictive of future job performance. Public safety departments are exempt from the application of this code section. The human resources department shall promulgate and this council may from time to approve administrative policies and procedures to facilitate the implementation of this code section. 
(Ord. No. 88-11, 2-9-88; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 3-13-12; Ord. No. 15-21, § 1,5-26-15) 
Sec. 16B-1-4. - Interpretation. 
The regulations are intended to cover most personnel problems and actions likely to be encountered. Those not specifically covered shall be interpreted by the personnel officer subject to the concurrence of the director of administration in keeping with the intent of the Charter and the objectives of those regulations. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 4, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-1-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-21, § 1, adopted April 13, 1999, repealed former § 16B-1-5, which pertained to general duties of the personnel review board; composition of the board, term of members; appeals and grievances and derived from Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 5, adopted Aug. 17, 1971; Ord. No. 71-287, § 1, adopted Nov. 2, 1971; Ord. No. 75-20, § 3, adopted March 18, 1975; Ord. No. 80-85, § 1, adopted July 15, 1980; and Ord. No. 89-39, adopted April 11, 1989. Section 2 of Ord. No. 99-21 adopted Human Resources Policies Numbered 220-501 Work Rules , 220-502 Disciplinary Action , 220-503 Involuntary Termination of Employment , 220-504 Fair Treatment Policy , and 220-505 Personnel Review Board, dated April 1, 1999; official copies of said policies shall be maintained in the office of the city manager. 
Sec. 16B-1-6. - Veterans' preference. 
Procedures concerning honorably discharged veterans of any war will conform with Article III, Section VII, Paragraph XXIV, of the Constitution of the State of Georgia providing that equal preference be awarded such veterans as exists under Federal Civil Service Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 6, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-1-7. - Enforcement and administration. 
The responsibility and authority for the enforcement and administration of the rules and regulations set forth herein are vested in the department of administration. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 1, § 7, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-1-8. - Extension of the merit system. 
Upon the initial extension of the merit system to a program that has been established outside of the merit system, an incumbent may obtain permanent status through an open competitive examination; or if he has a specified period of service in the agency, at its discretion he may obtain permanent status if he passes a noncompetitive qualifying examination. If he does not pass, such employee may be retained in the position in which he has incumbency preference without acquiring the right of merit system status. An employee with permanent status under a merit system meeting these standards will retain comparable status if the employing agency is placed under the jurisdiction of another merit system. 
(Ord. No. 75-20, § 4, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-1-9. - Merit system executive. 
The Columbus Merit System of Personnel Administration will be administered by a qualified merit system executive who shall be the personnel officer. 
(Ord. No. 75-20, § 5, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-1-10. - Merit system review committee. 
(a)  A committee to be known as the merit system review committee is formally established. The composition of the merit system review committee shall consist of the city manager and the sheriff of Muscogee County as permanent members of the committee. The personnel officer and the affirmative action officer shall serve as permanent ex officio members and shall not have the right to vote. Other members of the committee shall consist of five department directors as voting members of the committee, who shall serve for one-year terms commencing July 1st of each year. The following department directors for even-numbered years shall consist of: The director of administration, the director of the department of engineering, the director of the department of finance, the director of department of community development, and the chief of the fire department. The following department directors for odd-numbered years shall consist of: The director of parks and recreation, the Muscogee County Tax Commissioner, director of the department of public works, director of the department of transportation and the chief of police. 
(b)  The general duties of this committee shall consist of: 
(1)  A continuous review and appraisal of the position classifications within the merit system; 
(2)  An examination of individual problems resulting from application of the merit system that may result in inequity or administrative problems; and 
(3)  An examination of special classes of problems that may arise from application of the merit system. 
(c)  The committee shall have authority to review and act upon requests for reclassification or upgrading of persons in the merit system on an individual basis. Also, the committee shall review and act upon requests for entry of new personnel in grades and steps higher than those normally specified for entry level. 
The merit system review committee shall make recommendations upon the request for reclassification without regard to identity of individual. 
The committee shall receive request for reclassification from full-time elected or appointed officers who serve in a supervisory capacity and department directors only. 
The official requesting reclassification shall be invited to be present at the committee meeting when his request for reclassification is being considered. 
Members of this committee, other than the City Manager, shall not be eligible to cast a vote in committee action directly affecting his own department. 
The committee shall make a determination on each request for reclassification within 45 days after the receipt of request. 
The committee shall not have the authority to act to create new positions or new grades or new classifications, and in this respect, it shall function as a recommending body to the council only. In its continuous review of the merit system, the committee may identify other problems which shall be referred to the council for appropriate action. 
(d)  The merit system review committee shall be authorized to meet from time to time as need arises and conduct its business under rules or guidelines established by the committee. 
(e)  The council shall receive reports from the merit system review committee which contain (1) the actions taken by the Committee; and (2) an up-to-date version of the merit system position classifications, grades, and pay scales in January, April, July and October of each calendar year. Recommendations of the committee for council action shall be submitted as need arises. 
(Ord. No. 78-96, §§ 1—5, 8-15-78; Ord. No. 83-1, § 1, 1-4-83; Ord. No. 84-89, 9-25-84; Ord. No. 84-90, 9-25-84) 
ARTICLE II. - POSITION CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

Sec. 16B-2-1. - Definitions. 
The position classification plan is the official or approved system of grouping positions into appropriate classes, including (1) a schematic index to the class specifications; (2) the class specifications and (3) rules of administration. It covers all positions under the merit system as specified by the Charter, section 8-302. 
(a)  For position classification purposes, a "position" is a group of currently assigned duties and responsibilities requiring the full or part-time employment of one person. A position may be occupied or vacant. 
(b)  A "class" is a group of positions (or one position) that: (1) has similar duties and responsibilities, (2) requires like qualifications, experience and minimum training and, (3) can be equitably compensated by the same salary range. 
(c)  The "class title" is the official designation or name of the class as stated in the class specification. It shall be used on all personnel records and actions. Working or office titles may be used for purposes of internal administration. 
(d)  "Permanent full-time employee." An employee whose position requires him to work not less than 12 months per calendar year, and not less than 40 hours a week is categorized as a permanent full-time employee. 
(e)  "Permanent part-time employee." An employee whose position requires him to work not less than nine months per calendar year and not less than 20 hours per week is categorized as a permanent part-time employee. 
(f)  "Part-time employee." An employee whose position requires him to work not less than nine months per calendar year but less than 20 hours per week is categorized as a part-time employee. 
(g)  "Temporary employee." An employee whose position requires him to work less than nine months per calendar year regardless of the number of hours worked per week is categorized as a temporary employee. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 1, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 72-75, 5-2-72; Ord. No. 75-20, § 6, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-2-2. - Responsibility for administration. 
The personnel officer under the director of administration shall be responsible for administering the position classification plan. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 2, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 75-20, § 7, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-2-3. - Allocation of positions; creation of classes. 
After the establishment of a new position has been approved, the appointing authority involved shall complete a position description covering the duties and responsibilities of each proposed position. The personnel officer shall allocate the position to one of the classes in the classification plan. If a suitable class does not exist, he shall recommend the establishment of a new class and after the adoption of the new class, as provided in section 8-304 of the Charter, shall allocate the position to it. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 3, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-4. - Allocation appeals. 
If an employee has facts which indicate to him that his position is improperly allocated, he may request the personnel officer to review the allocation of his position with the knowledge of his appointing authority. Such request shall be submitted in writing and shall contain a statement of justification. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 4, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-5. - Maintenance of plan. 
(a)  Each time a vacancy occurs, a position description shall be completed by the appointing authority and submitted to the personnel officer for a review of the allocation of the position. The personnel officer may waive this requirement in cases where he has determined that no material changes have occurred. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each appointing authority to submit to the personnel officer new position descriptions for all affected positions each time a department or division under his jurisdiction is permanently or substantially reorganized. 
(c)  The personnel officer may require departments or employees to submit position descriptions on a periodic basis, or any time he has reason to believe that there has been a change in the duties and responsibilities of one or more positions. 
(d)  Each time a new class is established, a class specification shall be written and incorporated in the existing plan. The class title shall be added to the schematic list of titles. Likewise an abolished class shall be deleted from the classification plan by removing the class title from the schematic list of titles. 
(e)  Periodically, after the adoption of these regulations, the personnel officer shall conduct a general review of the classification plan. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 5, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-6. - Interpretation of class specifications. 
The class specifications are descriptive and not restrictive. The use of a particular description as to duties, qualifications or other factors shall not be held to exclude others of similar kind of quality. They are intended to indicate the kinds of positions which shall be allocated to the classes established. In a series of classes such as the police classes, the specifications for all classes should be reviewed as a unit. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 6, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-7. - Official copy of the position classification plan. 
The personnel officer shall be responsible for maintaining an official copy of the position classification plan. The official copy shall include a schematic list of class titles and class specifications plus all amendments thereto. A copy of the official plan shall be available for inspection by the public under reasonable conditions during business hours. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 7, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-8. - Amendments to the position classification plan. 
Each time a new class of positions should be established or a current class of positions abolished, the personnel officer shall make a study and submit his findings and recommendations to the director, department of administration, for processing in accordance with section 8-304 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 8, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-2-9. - Position classification plan in force. 
The position classification plan shall be considered a part of this section and have the same force and effect as these personnel regulations. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 2, § 9, 8-17-71) 
ARTICLE III. - PAY PLAN 

Sec. 16B-3-1. - New appointees. 
(a)  Generally, a new employee shall be paid the minimum rate of pay for his class. 
(b)  If the personnel officer determines that it is not possible to recruit qualified employees at the established entrance salary, after having been notified of the vacancy and having been allowed a reasonable time to recruit for the position, he may, at the request of the appointing authority, authorize the appointment of a qualified applicant at a higher step of the range, subject to approval by the director of administration and with the concurrence of the city manager, provided that all other employees in the same class of position in the same department are adjusted in salary to the same step not later than the beginning of the next quarter. If the salary of any employee in the same class in the same department is not adjusted in accordance with this section the appointing authority must obtain prior approval from the director of administration and with the concurrence of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 1, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 75-20, § 8, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-3-2. - Promotions. 
When an employee is promoted to a position in a higher class, his salary shall be increased to the minimum rate for the higher class. In the case of overlapping ranges and the employee to be promoted is at or above the minimum step of the class to which promoted, the promoted employee shall be increased to the dollar step immediately above his present salary which provides a minimum bi-weekly increase of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 2, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 89-106, § 1, 9-26-89) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 89-106, adopted Sept. 26, 1989, § 1 of which amended § 16B-3-2, reads as follows: "Section 2. This Ordinance shall be retroactive for those employees promoted or appointed after July 1, 1988, provided that at the time of the promotion or appointment, such employees were in a regular step as a result of the implementation of the pay plan in effect on July 1, 1987. 
Sec. 16B-3-2.1. - Promotional pay policy guidelines for public safety and general government pay programs. 
Promotional pay policy guidelines for the public safety and general government pay programs are: 
(1)  Public safety and general government employees that are selected for promotion will receive the greater of (a) a three percent pay increase of current salary for each pay grade that the new position exceeds the current position, limited to a maximum increase of ten percent or, (b) the minimum rate for the new position. 
(2)  This section is retroactive to April 29, 1997. 
(Ord. No. 97-129, § 2, 11-11-97; Ord. No. 01-88, § 1, 9-18-01) 
Editor's note— The provisions of Ord. No. 97-129, § 2, adopted Nov. 11, 1997, which amended Ch. 16B of the Code, have been included herein as § 16B-3-2.1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 16B-3-3. - Demotions. 
When an employee is demoted to a lower class position, he shall be paid at a rate which is within the approved range for the lower class position. The rate of pay shall be set by the director of administration with the recommendation of the department head concerned. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 3, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-4. - Reallocations downward. 
When an employee's position is reallocated to a lower class position and his present salary is above the maximum for the lower class, the employee shall be permitted to continue at his present rate of pay during period of incumbency (except in event of general service-wide reductions) but shall not be entitled to a salary increase. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 4, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-5. - Reinstated employees. 
A reinstated employee shall be paid at a salary rate within the approved salary range for the position in which he is reinstated. The rate of pay shall be set by the director of administration. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 5, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-6. - Part-time employment. 
When employment is on a part-time basis, only the proportionate part of the rate for the time actually employed shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 6, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 81-47, enacted June 9, 1981, deleted former § 16B-3-7 in its entirety, and enacted, in lieu thereof, a new § 16B-15-4. The deleted provisions pertained to overtime and derived from Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 7, enacted Aug. 17, 1971. 
Sec. 16B-3-8. - Administrative wage adjustment. 
(a)  The wages of each employee in Steps A through C of his job classification shall be reviewed annually by his immediate supervisor and appointing authority for the purpose of making recommendations for the following year. The wages of each employee in Steps D and E of his job classification shall be reviewed biennially for the purpose of making recommendations for the following year. All of the employee's personnel records, including attendance, tardiness, performance, and length of service shall be considered in making a wage recommendation, with major emphasis placed on the objective evaluation of services rendered. Continued development of personal skills through education and training, established as criteria by the department heads with the approval of the city manager, will be considered in making recommendations for pay increases. 
(b)  In all cases where wage increases are recommended, a certificate or a performance rating from the immediate supervisor, with the approval of the appointing authority, stating the reason for the recommendation, shall be submitted to the personnel officer. 
(c)  Departmental requests for wage adjustments shall be endorsed by the personnel officer and forwarded to the city manager via the director of administration for action. The city manager shall have the authority to approve or deny any request for a merit raise, based upon his review of length of service requirements and his evaluation of the employee's job performance record. 
(d)  The merit raise review contemplated by subsections (a), (b) and (c) herein shall be conducted annually for an effective pay raise in each year hereafter commencing July 1, 1988, for employees in Step A through G of their grade. The merit raise review contemplated by subsections (a), (b) and (c) herein shall be conducted biennially for an effective pay raise at two-year intervals commencing July 1, 1988, for employees in Steps H and I of their grade. All merit raises for employees in Steps A through G of their grade shall be effective at the beginning of the pay period in which the anniversary date of their appointment or promotion occurs. All merit raises for employees in Step H and I of their grade shall be effective at the beginning of the pay period in which the bi-anniversary date of their appointment or promotion occurs. 
(e)  When an employee is promoted to a higher class or pay grade, his promotional salary adjustment will be in accordance with section 16B-3-2. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 8, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 73-2, § 1, 1-2-73; Ord. No. 74-11, § 1, 1-2-74; Ord. No. 88-70, 6-21-88; Ord. No. 89-107, 9-26-89) 
Sec. 16B-3-8.1. - Tenure eligibility for promoted or individually reclassified employees; permanent anniversary or appointment date. 
(a)  In order to preserve equity amount all Columbus Consolidated Government employees with respect to their classifications and tenure, it is hereby ordained by the Council of Columbus, Georgia as follows: 
Effective July 1, 1998, the employee's original date of hiring will replace and supersede all anniversary dates whether established by date of employment, reclassification, promotion, or demotion as the date for implementation of any annual pay for performance increase for general government employees and public safety employees. 
Effective July 1, 1998, regular full-time employees are to be evaluated and rated at least once a year during the 30-day period prior to the date of hiring (anniversary). The evaluation will serve as a performance indicator to the employee and as a basis for performance increases. 
(b)  The tenure required for any merit increase shall not be deemed interrupted or negated by an individual reclassification or promotion within such tenure. 
(Ord. No. 74-49, 3-12-74; Ord. No. 89-108, 9-26-89; Ord. No. 97-95, 9-9-97) 
Sec. 16B-3-9. - Pay plans in effect. 
The pay plans in effect on the date of the adoption of the Charter shall remain in effect until modified in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and these regulations. When adopted, the pay plan for the government shall be considered a part of this article and have the same force and effect as these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 9, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-10. - Revision of pay plan. 
The personnel officer, when he deems it necessary, shall examine the pay plan for the purpose of revision and on the basis of conclusions reached through this examination, make recommendations for amendments as prescribed by section 8-304 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 10, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-3-11. - Adoption and amendment of pay plan. 
When approved as prescribed by section 8-304 of the Charter, such plan shall constitute the consolidated city's pay schedule for classes of positions in the merit system as prescribed by the Charter, section 8-302, for the ensuing fiscal year and thereafter until a new pay plan shall be adopted in the manner prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 3, § 11, 8-17-71) 
ARTICLE IV. - APPLICATIONS AND EXAMINATIONS 

Sec. 16B-4-1. - Announcements of examinations and position openings. 
All examinations, assembled or unassembled, for positions in the merit system shall be publicized by posting announcements in the office of the personnel officer on official bulletin boards, by utilizing communications media and the state employment service, and such means as the personnel officer deems advisable, to insure that all segments of the population are informed. The announcements shall specify the title and salary range of the class for which the examination is announced; the date, time, place, manner of making application; qualification requirements for admission to the tests; and other pertinent information. Assembled examinations shall be announced at least 15 days in advance of the closing date for the receipt of applications. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 1, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-4-2. - Application forms. 
Applications shall be made on forms provided by the personnel officer. Such forms shall require information covering training, experience, age and other pertinent information. All applications shall be signed by the person applying. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 2, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-4-2.1. - Criminal records background check. 
Based on the requirements of the job for which they are applying, all applicants for initial employment or a new position with the consolidated government shall consent in writing to a state and/or national criminal records background check and/or shall provide fingerprints in such form and of such quality as shall be acceptable for submission to the Georgia Crime Information Center and the National Crime Information Center. The consolidated government will use this information consistent with federal law, and all appropriate notices required by such laws will be provided. 
(Ord. No. 03-58, § 1, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 12-13, § 2, 3-13-12) 
Sec. 16B-4-3. - Employment requirements. 
All permanent positions shall be open to citizens of the United States and persons legally authorized to work in this country who meet the requirements as listed on the public announcement of the position. Such requirements may include but shall not be limited to the following factors: Experience, education, age, character, and physical condition. Applications will not be accepted for permanent full-time employment from any person less than 18 years of age, except high school graduates or equivalents and part-time student employees. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 3, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 12-13, § 3, 3-13-12) 
Sec. 16B-4-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Former § 16B-4-4, which pertained to residence requirements for merit system employees, was repealed by Ord. No. 86-30, enacted March 25, 1986. The repealed provisions derived from Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 4, enacted Aug. 17, 1971. 
Sec. 16B-4-5. - Rejection of applications. 
The personnel officer may reject an application which indicates that the applicant is deficient in any or all of the requirements as specified in the public announcement of the examination. An applicant may also be rejected for the practice or attempted practice of fraud or deception in the completion of his application, or if his past record of employment is determined to be unsatisfactory by the personnel officer. Notice of rejection shall be mailed to the rejected applicant by the personnel officer, stating the reason therefor. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 5, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-4-6. - Open competitive examinations. 
Positions to be filled by recruitment from outside of the merit system may be filled through examinations open to the public. Examinations may be assembled or unassembled or continuously open and/or announced for specified dates and may include, but shall not be limited to rating of training and experience, written, oral, physical or performance tests or any combination of these as determined by the personnel officer. They may take into consideration such factors as education, experience, aptitude, knowledge, skill, character, physical fitness, or any other qualifications which in the judgment of the personnel officer enter into determination of the relative fitness of applicants. The personnel officer may require applicants to submit proof of their age, citizenship and military service at the time of the examination and shall keep a record of this information. Care shall be taken that the examinations shall not be prejudicial to any applicant, regardless of race, color, creed, sex or national origin. Furthermore, the examinations and other requirements shall be limited to the qualifications needed for the particular job in question. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 6, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 16B-4-7. - Promotional examinations. 
Promotional examinations shall be open to all regular employees in the merit system who meet the necessary requirements as determined by the personnel officer. 
(Ord. No. 71-213, Ch. 4, § 7, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 75-20, § 9, 3-18-75) 
Sec. 16B-4-8. - Method of rating.
