ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Badge—Possession of official badge only. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession a police badge of the city except the official police badge. 
(Ord. of 5-2-23, § 2) 
Sec. 17-2. - Same—Possession by authorized personnel only. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession the police badge mentioned in the preceding section, except a police officer of the city or some officer authorized by law to exercise police power for the city. 
(Ord. of 5-2-23, § 3) 
Sec. 17-3. - Same—Sale, delivery, etc.; certificate, required, by whom signed. 
It shall be unlawful, in the city or its police district, for any person to sell or deliver to any other person any badge containing the word "detective", "police", "sheriff", "deputy sheriff", "marshal", "deputy marshal", or other words descriptive of a law enforcement or peace officer, unless the person to whom such badge is sold or delivered first furnishes to the person so selling or delivering such badge a written certificate showing that the person to whom the badge is sold or delivered is legally the type of officer to which such badge applies. Such certificate is to be signed by the officer or legal authority charged with the appointment of such type of officer, except that if the wording on such badge is descriptive of any officer elected by vote of the people the certificate shall be signed by the Ordinary of Muscogee County. 
(Ord. of 10-1-46, § 1) 
Sec. 17-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 17-4, relative to enforcement of city laws within the police district, derived from Ord. of Sept. 5, 1923, § 1, and Ord. No. 68-225, § 1, adopted Sept. 16, 1968, was repealed by Ord. No. 78-65, § 1, enacted May 23, 1978. 
Sec. 17-5. - Jurisdiction. 
The jurisdiction of the police officers of Columbus, Georgia shall be the entire area of Columbus, Georgia. The police officers are hereby authorized to make cases for violations of the law, to issue summons, and to take other actions necessary to the fulfillment of their duties and responsibilities. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 2; Ord. No. 78-65, § 4, 5-23-78) 
Sec. 17-6. - Stolen, abandoned or impounded property—Disposition by police. 
All personal property (except as herein stated) now in the possession of the police department of the City of Columbus, or which may hereafter come into the possession of said department, where said property has been stolen, or where the ownership is unknown to the chief of police, or where such property has been impounded for violation of any law relating to traffic for a period of 60 days and has not been claimed or called for by the owner or other person having the right to possession of the impounded property, shall be handled and disposed of as follows: 
All such property shall be safely kept, for a period of 60 days after being received by the department, in a room provided therefor at police headquarters, and if after the expiration of that time the same shall be unclaimed by a person making proof of ownership satisfactory to the chief of police, such property shall, by the chief of police, be advertised and sold. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 1; Ord. No. 62-133, § 1, 12-27-62) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 62-133 amended the ordinance of June 20, 1938, from which above § 17-6 is derived, to add the provision relating to impounded property in the first paragraph. 
Sec. 17-7. - Same—Notice of sale, posting publication, information. 
The advertisement of such property for sale shall, (except as hereinafter stated), be posted at the door of the County Court House in Muscogee County, Georgia, and published one time in a newspaper regularly published in the city, such posting and publication to be at least ten days before the date set by the chief of police for such sale. The advertisement shall give a description of the articles to be sold, and the time when and the place where the sale will take place. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 2) 
Sec. 17-8. - Same—Time and place of sales. 
All such sales shall be held in front of police headquarters in the city, between the hours of eleven o'clock a.m., Central Standard Time, and three o'clock p.m., Central Standard Time, and shall be at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash; provided, however, such a sale of personal property may be held at any place within the corporate limits of the city, which is specified in the advertisement of such sale. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 3; Ord. of 9-21-54, § 1) 
Sec. 17-9. - Same—Perishable property. 
Any unclaimed perishable property coming into the possession of the police department may, in the discretion of the chief of police, be sold by him at either public or private sale, either without advertisement or upon such advertisement, as he deems expedient. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 4) 
Sec. 17-10. - Same—Destruction of weapons or claim by finder. 
(a)  The preceding sections relating to disposition of stolen or abandoned property will not authorize the sale of any weapons that are illegal per se or that are prohibited by law, nor shall the sale of any weapons under the preceding sections be consummated unless all provisions regulating such sales imposed by local, state, or federal law are met. The police chief shall have the authority to conduct the sale of weapons in bulk and to receive bulk bids on any given number of weapons available for sale. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the finder of the property, unless he is an employee of a law enforcement agency of Columbus, Georgia, or convicted of a felony, may claim such property after the expiration of the 60-day period required by this section, and provided such weapon is a legal weapon. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 7; Ord. No. 80-86, § 1, 7-22-80; Ord. No. 91-31, 5-7-91) 
Sec. 17-11. - Same—Record of disposition, information. 
The chief of police shall keep a record showing when such property came into the possession of the police department, where found or from whom taken, its description, when claimed and by whom, or when advertised and when sold, and the amount for which each article is sold. All funds derived from such sales shall be paid by the chief of police to the treasurer of the city. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 5) 
Sec. 17-12. - Same—Animals excluded from provisions. 
This chapter shall not apply in the cases of animals coming into the possession of or impounded by the police department, but such animals shall be handled and disposed of in accordance with existing provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. of 6-20-38, § 6) 
Cross reference— Provision relevant to impounding of animals, §§ 5-5, 5-18. 
Sec. 17-13. - Metro drug task force. 
(a)  Authorization. The chief of the police department and the county sheriff are authorized to participate in the joint law enforcement activities of the metro drug task force to the extent permitted by applicable law, with such task force described in detail by documents entitled "Metro Narcotics Task Force" which are on file in the office of the clerk of council. 
(b)  Forfeited money or currency; administration. Money and currency which is forfeited under the Georgia Controlled Substances Act (including money and currency from forfeited or condemned property) which vests in and which is paid into the county treasury as county funds shall be released from the county treasury and shall be jointly administered by the chief of the police department and the county sheriff and designated for use by the members of their respective departments in conjunction with law enforcement activities of the metro drug task force under the following conditions and within the following limits: 
(1)  The amount so released, administered and designated shall be placed in a separate account which shall not exceed $100,000.00 at any one time. 
(2)  All money and currency in said account shall be derived from cases involving members of the Columbus Police Department or members of the Muscogee County Sheriff's Department in conjunction with law enforcement activities of the Metro Drug Task Force. 
(3)  No provision contained herein shall affect any accounts previously established for the use of the police department or the county sheriffs department pursuant to Ordinance Number 82-64 and the provisions of Ordinance Number 82-64 shall remain in full force and effect. 
(c)  Use of funds. The money and currency contained in the account shall be used to defray nonbudgeted narcotic investigative costs as permitted under O.C.G.A. section 16-13-49, and these funds shall supplement any funds budgeted for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 89-48, §§ 1—3, 4-25-89) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 89-48, adopted April 25, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of 1—3 as § 17-13 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 17-14. - Duties of police chief. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be the chief executive officer of the Columbus Police Department. The chief shall be responsible to the mayor for the overall operations of the department. The chief of police is the ranking officer of the department and shall have authority over all personnel, sworn and nonsworn, within the department. 
(b)  The chief shall be responsible for the selection, training, assignment and promotion of all personnel. The chief shall have the authority to discipline, including the termination of, any departmental personnel. 
(c)  The chief is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations and to establish policy and procedure governing the conduct of departmental employees and the activities and operations of the police department. The chief is responsible for the fiscal management of the department and shall prepare and submit an annual budget to the mayor and city manager. 
(d)  The chief of police shall make a monthly written report to the mayor outlining the activities, accomplishments and condition of the department. 
(e)  The chief may delegate any of the responsibilities of the office to any of the subordinates within the police department. 
(Ord. No. 91-117, 12-13-91) 
Editor's note— The provisions of Ord. No. 91-117, adopted Dec. 31, 1991, amending Ch. 17 by adding a new section, were included as § 17-14 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference— Office of chief of police, § 17-21.2. 
Sec. 17-15. - Forfeited money. 
(a)  Money which is forfeited pursuant to any state or federal law, including money obtained from the sale of forfeited property, which is made available to the police department or the sheriff shall be accounted for and used under the following conditions: 
(1)  All forfeited money made available to the police department shall be deposited in the police forfeiture fund, which is hereby established for the exclusive uses provided herein. All forfeited money made available to the sheriff shall be deposited in the sheriff's forfeiture fund, which is hereby established for the exclusive uses provided herein. The police forfeiture fund and the sheriff's forfeiture fund shall be maintained by the finance director as special revenue funds in a manner which conforms to all applicable state and federal laws or regulations governing forfeitures, and to all laws and regulations governing the accounting and use of public funds. 
(2)  The money contained in the funds established herein shall be used for unbudgeted operating expenditure of the police department and sheriff, but in no event shall forfeited money be used for personnel expenses or for any purpose prohibited by state or federal law or to supplant funds which otherwise would be made available to the police department or sheriff through the annual budget. The mayor/director of public safety will receive quarterly audit reports of the funds activity. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, the money contained in the funds established herein may be used as matching funds for grants if permitted by the state or federal laws under which the forfeiture are obtained. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to forfeitures made available to Metro Narcotics Task Force pursuant to section 17-13 of the Columbus Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Ordinance No. 82-64 is hereby repealed. The finance director shall take such actions as are necessary to place funds currently in the sheriff's account established therein in the sheriff's forfeiture fund and to place funds in the police department account established therein in the police forfeiture fund. 
(Ord. No. 98-22, §§ 1—3, 3-10-98) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 98-22, §§ 1-3, adopted March 10, 1998, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as § 17-15 herein was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 17-16—17-21. - Reserved.

No. 80-62, § 1, adopted May 20, 1980; and Ord. No. 80-71, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 10, 1980, was repealed by § 2 of Ord. No. 81-96, enacted Sept. 22, 1981. Said § 2 further enacted, in lieu of the repealed provisions, a new Art. II, §§ 17-21.1—17-21.6 as herein set forth; and §§ 3—5 of the ordinance enacted new Arts. III—V, §§ 17-22—17-34. b.  Desk services section.

(2)  Bureau of administrative services, and within the bureau, there shall be the following sections: 
a.  Crime prevention/community relations. 
b.  Personnel. 
c.  Training. 
d.  Conditional discharge. 
(Ord. No. 81-96, § 2, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 84-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-10-84; Ord. No. 87-96, § 1, 7-21-87; Ord. No. 88-113, §§ 1, 2, 11-15-88; Ord. No. 92-50, § 1, 6-16-92)
